i said thank you..i wish i didnt have to though.  we arrived there a little early since we were staying at the vdara next door so it was small walk to lemongrass. i told the host i had reservations and that we were 15mins early but she immediately seated us in a booth i had asked for and our server was great/polite/attentive. he was def great in customer service, wished i got his name! the aura of lemongrass was interesting..it was pretty dark than i expected it to be from looking at it from the front of the resturant.  my bf and i ordered their chicken satay as an apetitizer and damn it was so authentic and delicious! im thai, so they def got it started on the right foot! their thai teas were amazingly great and again authentic. our main entrees were the rib eye steak with tamarind sauce and basil beef fried rice. we both shared the entrees and it was amazingly YUUUMMYY!  the rib eye is something i enjoyed the most and would reccommend.  the basil fried rice was surprisingly spicy..esp for myself..i loveeeee spicy food so that was a lot coming from me.  later our server came to surprise my bf with their mango and sweet rice dessert witha  candle in it. guess what, it was complimentary! it is originally $7 but since it was a bday dessert they gave it to us for free!  overall, this is a much cheaper alternative to blossom but still a great place to eat and get full...also to have a nice private lil dinner.

hKPpcY9irvvb9R4Wji-g9g.text: So I really want to give this place 3.5 stars but there isn't that option on my phone. So I will be on the safe side and put three. It was pretty good. One of the fancier Thai places I have been to. But I have had better Thai food at small mom and pop shops. We are staying at Aria and we needed an easy place to dine with a two year old. This seemed to be a better option than the cafe.  The service was fast and cordial. They left us alone, in a good way, for the most part. My water was constantly refilled.   We ordered the chicken satay. The chicken was moist but I have had better peanut sauce at many other places. So I would probably recommend something else. It didn't wow me but I still enjoyed eating it. Next we got the pad Thai with prawns and the soft shell crab salad. Both were tasty, lots of flavors. The salad had mint, onion, pepper and some other herbs and spices. The crab was good but a little salty for my taste. The pad Thai was pretty good. Not much to say about it though.   All in all it was decent food and casual but nice atmosphere. I would not travel out of my way to eat here and I wouldn't really recommend someone to go there either. But if you do find yourself at Aria and craving some fancier Thai food then go ahead and try it.

QUIRgiLzP6rO4miUx0V1-Q.text: The best thing about this place was the decor/ambiance!  I loved it...would give it 5 stars!  The food sort of BLAND!  We ordered: Lemongrass soup- it was decent except sooo many lemongrass pieces it was hard to avoid not eating them.  I wish they would have drained them out.    Stir Fry- really was not what we expected.  The plate came out with bok choy with like a thick/clear garlic sort of sauce.  It tasted good, but we were expecting a veggie stir fry.  Pad See Ew- ZERO flavor!    Sorry but what a disappointment in the food.

UDXt0ezkY_NkWmJjrEUvzw.text: We stopped by this restaurant as we were heading back up to our room (Aria sky suites ftw!). I'll keep this short since I was a bit tipsy that night (lol off of two Midori Sours - sad I know!).  I ordered the Papaya salad ($10). It has the fish/crab sauce and has a strong smell, but it's delicious! A bit pricey compared to other Thai places, but the salad tasted better than most papaya salads that I've from these other places. It's not as spicy as other ones, but I actually like the level of spicyness here because I prefer to not have a runny nose while I'm eating it. My boyfriend ordered the drunken noodles with seafood ($20). It had large pieces of shrimp and squid that were very flavorful. They give you enough to feed two people - I was helping him finish his. It's also quite spicy, so beware! I do enjoy eating spicy food, but wow... my tongue was burning after a few bites! My friend had the sesame chicken ($17) with a small bowl of rice ($3). it was pretty good - I didn't detect any MSG in it, so that's good. The place is pretty big too - definitely enough for two people, and the chicken is still crispy, despite being coated in so much sauce.  Service was great - the food didn't take very long to cook, although there were hardly any customers since it was around 1:30am in the morning. Our waiters were quick in bringing out our drinks, and were nice enough box our unfinished entrees. They also refilled out waters frequently, considering how much we drank due to the spicy noodles.  Overall, I really like this place. It's spacious inside, there's booth and regular seating (I like sitting in booths!), and the tables are spacious. They're also accommodating to larger parties, even late at night. If you're not craving Thai food in Vegas and looking for a cheap fill to satisfy your munchies, then this is not the place for you. They'll be seeing me again.

lyNO1u83aZe-8hku6SQgbA.text: I don't think I ever need to come back here again. This place is over priced and portions are teeny. I ordered the soft shell crab salad ($25) and while it was filled with yummy soft shell crabs, it was too spicy and I finished it in about 4 bites. No kidding. We also ordered the lobster salad and steak salad and those were good too but also very tiny! The decor is nice but a bit too modern and the seating is awkward. I guess the prices are not bad for Vegas but unfortunately, Lemongrass is just not up to par.

GQif6sY8a00SqZXqb2rfyA.text: Was aight... For Americanized Asian food.. I had the schezwan spicy beef noodle soup. My friend had the seafood noodle soup which she thought was ok too.    For a restaurant in the Aria that's trying to cater to most of the asians who come to Vegas to gamble and party.. its an easy and quick alternative to getting a cab and going to the chinatown area of Las Vegas.  This is also one of the restaurants that is included in the list of comped restaurants in the Aria.

RG3nNsA3e-IOPIQy4fLFJg.text: If I could give this zero stars trust me I would. We had ordered Garlic Shrimp and Three Cups Chicken which both were supposed to have garlic flavor. The food came in 2 minutes indicating that it was not fresh. The food has no flavor of garlic.

tJy8f3N4M7xG4LtR7SvxAQ.text: Very nice place, but only decent Thai Food.  First off I would like to state that I am happy a Thai Place exists on the strip.  For that reason I think Lemongrass is awesome.  However, the decor falls way above the food.  I came here late on a Friday night with my friend who gets out of work after 11.  I mostly picked off his food as I had already eaten.  I tried the veg rolls, which were tasty but not amazing and the mango sticky rice.  Both were good but only mediocar.  Looking over the menu they had few vegetarian friendly options and mostly meaty dishes.  It seemed that rather than stick traditional thai style food the menu deviated a bit.  I would come again, but only if provoked  The decor is gorgeous.  High ceilings and rich brown flavors.  If your going on a date, and looking for someplace nice, classy and romantic.  I think you would be safe picking lemongrass.

5zxzc6jgNNoR2TSWVNoUVA.text: The food here was delicious and the service was very good.  Everything we ordered was cooked perfectly, and we are still craving it days later.  I recommend the steamed cod and the thai iced tea drink with rum.    They have some kinks to work out with the menu and pricing, which is why I won't give them five stars.  For example, they charged extra for rice, which I thought was weird.  Their portions were huge, so maybe they could reduce the portion size a bit and include rice?  But overall, a very good experience.

s019l5klUPHBmqBGuFpohg.text: Several good reviews on here, but my one experience was not.  Food was mediocre Thai.  I understand the modern fusion twist, but I have had dive Thai places much better than this.  Shared several dishes among companions, like drunken noodles, salmon, chicken satay, etc.  Food was not good value for the price $.  For what I consider one of the newer casinos in Vegas, the service was too slow.  Left the restaurant hungry.  I'm all for second chances, but with so many other choices in Vegas why would I come back?

NIUcd7YikI-DeQVODRQikA.text: not bad not great.    avoid their dimsum menu. very amateurish and probably their worst offerings.  curries are fair. but too sweet and with undercooked veggies.   their soup noodles are pretty good.  the meats used in their fried noodles and rice dishes are not terribly fresh. you can taste the freezer burn.

Sde0Ke1k9njhaMAqtJud0w.text: Conveniently located directly next to the elevators to our suite@Aria..   Of all the items we ordered.. I would say my favorite was the tamarind ribeye steak.. it was very juicy and moist.. and the tamarind dip was a really good touch  3.5 stars..

g73DqhA6Y5Kh57_dmYAt9g.text: Went to Lemon Grass on a whim. Food was pretty bad, mediocre at best. We ordered the chicken wings and eggrolls for an appetizer. Wings were flavorless, and looked way better than they tasted. Eggrolls were not special either. We ordered a noodle dish and a soup. Soup was ordered with a spice level of 4 out of 10. We like spicy food a lot, but I swear the waitress requested a 14 out of 10!  Damn hot!!!  I don't plan on going back to Lemon Grass, primarily due to the service (or lack there of) we received from our old grumpy waitress. She was not happy to be there, never smiled once and just lacked the most basic courtesies expected from a waitress at any restaurant, let alone Vegas. Definitely nice decor, but not worth the price. The negative sour vibe from the serving staff and waitress was enough for me to not recommend.

_q76vccHIaJBBeP8a34h3w.text: I love thai food especially after night of drinking..the crab is amazing and spicy sesame chicken is great..and egg drop soup..soft shell crab fried rice..yummmm

PhyljHrO0TbjUCCMGegLEQ.text: EXCELLENT SERVICE AND FOOD!   We went on a weeknight, close to midnight, there were probably only 3-4 tables with customers. We had a younger girl as our server and she was excellent! She made sure our drinks were never half full and that we were satisfied with out meal. The food itself is a nice mix of asian cusine. The portions are big and the food is very tasty. Definitely a place to try!

4XWnVle7_rv_5T4hHdi1RQ.text: This place has best thai food, we had singapore noodle, asked them to make it spicy and so they did. It was the best thai dish we have had in a while. Also their thai ice tea was awesome.

BEYhnfU3vax3GncfQIl4cA.text: We were staying at ARIA for the weekend , so before heading out to party the night away, one of my friend suggested we grab something to eat at the hotel... At first we wanted Sushi, But walked by Lemongrass and the place seems really cozy and cute so we just decided to walk in and try this place out.   Boy, was I glad we did.  The food was so good.  The menu consist of all the typical Thai entrees, like pad thai and all the thai soup BUT because we were in vegas, we wanted to go the exotic route and try different stuff on the menu.  There was 6 of us girls and we decided to do family style and order 6 entrees and shared.  We got the Soft shell fried rice, beef pepper udon noodles , fish cakes, a coconut soup , coconut flavored rib eyed and a WONTON NOODLE SOUP ( for the girl that was hungover from friday nite)    I must say...everything was really good but the soft shell fried rice... WOW.. the fried rice had big chunks of the crab meat in it.. and let me say.. they were not greedy with it at all.. there was also large soft shell crab on top of the fried rice.  IT was sooo GOOD.   the Rib eye wasnt too bad either , although im more of a seafood person than a meat eater.    The prices here , of course, was a bit pricey compared to other thai restaurant, BUT we are in Vegas!!.  But we all agreed that you get what you pay for and the food was worth the price!!

oG8DRHFMG8RynokF32EbtA.text: Lemongrass is definitely catered toward the Americanized tourist hoping to find something they believe is authentic Thai but can still satisfy their taste buds.  We came in on a Saturday evening and ordered quite a feast for a party of 6.  Among the popular dish that three of us ordered - the Drunken seafood noodles.  Being the only Asian at the table, I found my dish to be completely soaked in soy sauce and lacking in all other known Thai spices.  The two other people demolished their dishes.  I loved the Tom Yam Hed soup by far.  They used fresh mushrooms rather than dried mushrooms, which really brought out the smooth texture in the mushrooms.  The broth was the perfect level of spice and flavor.  I also had the Jelly fish appetizer, which I would avoid.  There was a weird after taste that left a weird tough texture on my tongue.  Jellyfish should melt in my mouth and I would say mine was undercooked.  One con:  When we announced a birthday at the table, the waiter said he would bring out some dessert.  Little did we know we were going to get charged for it!  A little strange because if we are going to pay for something, it would be nice to get a choice in ordering it.  Perhaps it was lost in translation.

vKvLKYH4PnJi9XxFRZaOTQ.text: liked it, maybe it was the good company or that i got quite tipsy, but definitely enjoyed the evening. we just walked in and sat at the bar, he had a couple of thai beers and i had a peach ginger cocktail that is now of my favs and will be added to my default drink list. we had the pad see ew (spice level of 10) and a pork and basil rice dish (spice level of 8). and they weren't kidding when they said it would be spicy, then again, i'm not know to handle my spice well, tho i can to a certain degree. the food was good, cooked well, nothing was over done from what i can recall. tho this may not be the best thai i've ever had, but not bad for a hotel restaurant. the drinks were good, the service was good. overall, a good experience =).

ZgVMZeFrbvV0cyRMjX9qCw.text: The food was ok. My friends and I were satisfied. If we had to eat there again, I wouldn't be disappointed. The waitstaff was fine. The decor was fine.

qjMUMmLICjWGsS_zl-shcQ.text: This is one of the best Thai places.  Very authentic.  Price is a bit on a pricey side but I got mine as comp. so that wasn't a problem, but I could see a problem for those that has to pay out of pocket because 3 dishes + 3 water come out to around $150.

WVtwsBFxX89wU6mu5c5K7Q.text: all dishes are kids size and expensive. they have great selection of dishes such as small bowl of talay soup for 18.00.our bill wa 140.00 for 2 person.ladies, don"t take your men here if you want to save money

6NM0PfzLb3qQqY-zGjvH8w.text: We ate here before going to a show in the same hotel.   When we asked the maitre'd what the difference was between the Lemongrass and the one across the way (Blossom), she said "They are fine dining and we're not" so I stayed.  The scallops were delicious but everything was just a bit too spicy for my taste.   The waiter seemed unhelpful when asked for his opinion on different dishes and cocktails.  One of the specialty cocktails ("something Leopard") tasted medicinal.  My biggest recommendation would be the salmon rolls for an appetizer.  They were really good.

Cm65NIlH4C1gUC8W8WZF2g.text: Overpriced, confusing hodgepodge. Typical Vegas restaurant with no identity. Even waiters were laughing at the selection in the Dim Sum cart. We asked if anything had chicken. The waiter stuck out his tongue and laughed, "Chicken feet!".  The food was ordinary. But the surrounding architecture is something to figure out as you try to figure out why you ate here. Very few real Thai dishes on menu.

Z7Tgyoa4g_qwGE2DroPqTA.text: we came to aria from palazzo cuz our friends wanted to eat at aria buffet and then got sidetracked at sportsbook and didn't want to leave. so my bf and i came here for lunch. we had the thai basil soup, red curry with shrimp, papaya salad, calamari and shrimp salad, har gow and siu mai. everything was delicious. it was $90 for the two of us including tax and tip. kind of pricey for thai food but it's at the aria so what do you expect? the service was impeccable as well.

KkNflRXWhNodwcdZABNWCA.text: When they brought me the wrong dish I tasted it first. No flavor and lots of oil. When they brought me the "right" dish I thought it was the worst pad Thai ever. Oily, oily, oily. When I said just bring me soup - it was so oily I didn't eat that either. What a waste of money. Go to Noodles at Bellagio next door. Or Panda Express for goodness sakes.

IoL2bHuY0ap8SvGSYLLgtw.text: This place was absolutely superb all-around.  The ambiance was great, the service top-notch, and the food was best of all!    I ordered what amounted to some bone-in chunks of chicken served in a large hot pot in a spicy thai sauce with fresh basil leaves mixed in.  The restaurant lets you pick the heat level, and as I like my food spicy, I selected a heat level of 8 (out of a choice of 1-10)  -- the food served matched my personal heat taste perfectly.    I found the prices moderately high for Thai food, but not for Vegas, nor for the service and swanky ambiance offered.  As far as portions go, the item I ordered came with *plenty* of food presented nicely, and I could not posibly have eaten any more... a *very* large portion in my book that probably could have fed two.  Service was absolutely top-notch.  The server always was on top of drink refills and knew the menu extremely well (warning me as I placed my order that my choice had bones still in the chunks of chicken, for example).  He even gave excellent advice on cocktail pairings with some liqours I have never heard of (that were great, by the way).  I am a hard customer to please, but I don't have a bad thing to say about the place and that is the highest compliment I can give.  Lemongrass may be the only Thai restaurant on the Strip, but when you have one *this* good, who needs another one?

FKClULhE0OW9pq1HGDkrlw.text: If you are looking for any type of Asian food in Las Vegas this is the place to go. Dim sum, pho, curry and noodle dishes aplenty. After just returning from Singapore a couple of months ago I was craving some Singaporean food. The Singaporean noodle dish did not disappoint. My wife had chicken pho which is not in the menu.  Beef pho is, just ask for chicken and they are happy to accommodate. Don't miss out on the table side dim sum either. Tony was our waiter and he is an extremely nice an efficient person. We really enjoyed our lunch and will be back for sure.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Singapore noodle. I got a 5 which is about as hot as you probably want to go. They go all the way to 10.

cxuQ69sIaaI28NUzCcs1vg.text: Food is excellent along with the server. They made mistake with the viet tea and they fix it. Order the duck red curry mild and it taste really good. Highly recommended

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Love the duck red curry and tai chen chicken

85Prae-hOmK4uNeP7YMc0w.text: Excellent thai food! Phad thai ghoong was great like in raleigh beach, service was good  Price was ok for a casino restaurant 75 usd with tax for 2 (with wine glasses which are pretty expensive!! )  Strongly recommend

np8zWcRl2C3SWwsY9d9vlQ.text: 90$ for 4 people, drinks, entrees, and 1 appetizer. Huge portions too. Talk about DEALIO for vegas standards/prices.  I'd highly recommend this restaurant for foodies on a budget since although Vegas has a tremendous set of fancy, amazing restaurants to offer, it's not within most people's price range (plus, it is extremely hard to book reservations for the places that are to die for like Robuchon!) so run towards the middle and go to Lemongrass. They strangely have dim sum at lunch hours...but besides that, they offer comfort food for $20 or less. Satisfying and delicious. The restaurant is beautiful too. If I stay at the Aria again I would def venture over here again and again!

8Hv8xZkS2ZPxAMH1r-OvKQ.text: Lemongrass At Aria -- EEKS methinks NOT fer sure!  What were we thinking going for Thai in Vegas anyway!? That explains why this place was the only one that we can get a reservation for a big party last minute.  The servers were all friendly... but not very attentive. We asked for water and followed up nicely 3 more times and it didnt come until we were pretty much done with our meal.  The food were nothing special. They were all blah and bland. We had their "best appetizer" prawn roll which looked amazing but it   was nowhere near any prawn or shrimp rolls Ive tried even in the hole in the wall type of places.   We tried pretty much all their noodle dishes. They were all not satisfying! Some dish were super spicy like the shredded pork and beancurd, and the menu didnt even say it was a spicy dish.   How can a Thai restaurant go wrong with Mango sticky rice? ... but they did. It just didnt hit the spot for us.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States

vFO84GXz1NwZd8f37RW_kg.text: I am not sure what other reviewers are talking about...This place was not good. That is putting it mildly.  The panang curry was swimming in its own grease and there were huge chunks of bone in the duck that was in the pool of grease.  The pad thai J was flavorless and the tofu was dried up little chunks.  The server was funny and friendly and the kirin was tasty.   If you are in the area, I would go to one of the many other places that are in the Aria...not here.

aJoAln3y5-gfzfHvREO7Ig.text: First of all - the decor is cool. The food and service? Not so much. Had cashew chicken and sweet and sour chicken and both were quite bland. Had to send the cashew chicken back as it was served lukewarm. Waiter was inattentive and slow - maybe because we didn't order drinks? Have had better Thai food at our local "hole in the wall".

vxuEz39SLrGd5FlmrltbJQ.text: Shocked no one has reviewed this yet? Or maybe i just couldn't find it but I searched really long and hard lol  VENUE: Cute little restaurant tucked in one the corners of the Aria Hotel. Atmosphere is intimate, with dim lighting (even at 10AM in the morning). Decor is pretty modern with regular seating and bar area seating. We were sat in the bar area - tables were small but they had this small mini table pull out (very clever and smart) for additional space. Also the chairs were super comfy. Basically like mini couches (to me), which makes me wonder how wonderful the regular area seating is if they were reluctant to sit us near the bar. I'm really not sure if this place is supposed to be more chinese or thai as there are both kinds of dishes on the menu.  FOOD/DRINK: Dim sum is pretty standard so far. Got the har gow and siu Mai. As far as taste goes, a speaking as someone who has tasted Dim Sum from some solid areas (San Francisco, Houston, etc.), I would say that it was not phenomenal. Not bad, just not what I prefer. If I had to describe the taste in a sentence, it would be, "Dim Sum for the average  American." Not to be offensive or anything, but my opinion is that you would like it if you haven't had better. All in all it was still pretty good, and my kudos goes out to the amount of shrimp they packed in each bite. That was one pleasant surprise that I enjoyed.  Of course, anyone who has eaten dim sum understands that you will never get full from it, so in addition to this Chinese morning tapas, we ordered off the menu. One of my favorite and wisest foodies told me that if a Thai restaurant doesn't offer Lard Na on their menu then they're not really authentic. I decided to dare Lemongrass and asked my server if they would make Lard Na for me. Two surprises: the first being that she knew that the dish was, and the second was that she was super accommodating about wanting to get it made. She even knew that there are various way you can serve the dish (more gravy like or a soupy pho-style). She charged me for the price of the Pad see ew. When it arrived, the beef was nicely marinated and tender. The noodles were slightly bland, but I will forgive it as it was not an item they typically make and serve. I should have known better because the gravy sauce with Lard Na takes a long time to get right.  SERVICE:  Our hostess and server were extremely helpful.  As we were in the bar area, the bartender was also helpful and came to check up on us. At the end when we were paying, my card had gotten rejected, and he came back and made some remark (I'm sure he intended it to be comedic) about how I should have let my boyfriend pay. I was slightly miffed and after making sure there was nothing wrong with my account (as many of you wanderlusters know, the bank might think someone stole your card if you suddenly make a purchase on the other side of the country), I asked the bartender to swipe it again. It went through. To which, he commented, "Yeah make sure there's funds in there." Really dude? I don't need your accounting advice.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xusZRZNizYV9C4w8MmVPzw.text: So I'm enjoying an afternoon of Vegas poker at the Aria with a few friends. We're throwing chips around, enjoying drinks, as well as our profits. None of us want to leave the table with the oil exec from Houston and the French tourist who likes to bluff. I don't know what it is but I really enjoy taking money off the French. Gonna have to look in to that. Anyway, I'm a little hungry and after my fourth greyhound I need some food. But I wanna keep it healthy and light so I call the brush. She hands me a menu to Lemongrass for table-side service which I will gladly tip her well for. I see brown rice on the menu for $5 and I ask the brush to tell them to add a side order of broccoli. She says no problem and I tip her $5 for ordering/picking it up.  She comes back a few minutes later with the bill and its for $24 and change?????? I'm  confused, and assume she mixed my order up with another but no. I tell her to hold the order and let me know what the $24 charge is for (I'm staying upstairs and assume they'd charge my room cc at some point). She said that the manager said they don't do sides of broccoli and had to order the vegetarian dinner. I again am confused and let her know the vegetarian dinner is full of brown rice, noodles, and a mixture of veggies and mushrooms (is that a vegetable or a fungus?). She said the manager said this is all they can do for me. I tell her to cancel the order and say keep the tip for your efforts.  After my button passes I take a walk across the casino to the restaurant, more like a cafe. The manager is extremely smug and rigid. I am utterly shocked by his lack of customer service to not only a gambling guest, but a hotel guest as well. He makes some snide comment about me not wanting to pay or not "having enough" to pay for my meal. Again, completely shocked I decide to make a statement and accidentally drop my wad of gambling c-notes on his counter which he picks up and hands back to me. Douchey as it was, this pompous cafe manager had to be put in his place.  I returned to the poker table where we shortly left to get some Nobu at Hard Rock. It was a great trip but this was more surprising than anything. I still love the Aria and their poker room, I'll just steer clear of this place.

MdF6VrzqcPvNb4yPy2O_Lw.text: Would definitely go back. Cocktails were excellent.  Main dish need some soy to give it flavor.

mT9dZPtJpwxuVDKjH9kWVQ.text: Lemongrass provided good Thai food but at Las Vegas prices. We split the three course fixed price menu ($59) that included several things. We added calamari and two drinks and were completely stuffed.   The calamari seemed to be battered in funnel cake batter- it was REALLY good. Chicken satay and prawn roll were included in the fixed price, they were good, nothing amazing. Main dishes were basil beef, chicken pad thai and something else... can't remember. The best part of the basil beef was the giant onion ring it was served in, kind of like a bowl.Desert was good as well, but don't remember what it was besides being in warm coconut milk.    Overall I was left with a ... meh.... impression. Very nice place, food was good, service was good. But seriously, how can you really spruce up Thai food? I get it locally where I live and pay $15 for food for two people with leftovers and its just as good. I wouldn't come here expecting to be impressed, its just plain old good Thai food.

rdB2wkXUdIgOKT0oxRPwsQ.text: Service is slow whether from preparing your food to waiting for them to refill your water glass. Not much of a True Thai food menu more like an Asian food fusion. But I do say I enjoy the "Mango with Sticky Rice" dessert.. Try that one for sure

oDm0ai5bCDyFEyXHSRbnLQ.text: Good food, good service... our appetizer were brought after our main course was already half done.  Though the main course was served pretty quickly

ilQw7XwYQw56gxCT5V93FQ.text: In the land of top rated restaurants, Lemongrass is by far one of the best! One of the only places to get wonderfully prepared seafood dishes at 1am! Even in Vegas. The service was respectful and prompt, no problem accommodating a party of 8 for late night dining. Affordable fine dining, no over inflation! Location is in the Aria, just a beautiful hotel to walk through. Will enjoy Lemongrass when we go back again for sure:)

BU4O5E9HvUjQvM3Xt-QVxA.text: I was in the mood for some soup so decided to come here since it was near my hotel. Restaurant is very nice as well as the ambiance.  Ordered chicken pho soup which was pretty good. They have dim sum but I didn't try any. This was the closest place that you can get pho on the strip.  Dishes were a little overpriced but it is expected since this restaurant is in Aria.  Service was very good and attentive. Would definitely come back for the soup and maybe to try the dim sum.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Noodles

OZdY_YDyDAiZ8wNZYfXkPw.text: At first, I was in disbelief that such a beautiful restaurant could have a relatively low rating. Upon further inspection of the bad reviews and a meal during a typical day of the week at 5:30PM, the general consensus is unfortunately True. The service was horrid, the food came out incredibly slow, and they never checked up on us once after the meal was out. I ordered Phad Thai and my mother ordered Phad See Ew expecting authentic or at least tasteful Thai food. I was already in a good mood because of the atmosphere and a good Thai tea. However, you just can't ignore the lack of flavor of both traditional dishes. Both dishes tasted like flavorless jello. I tend to be generous with my opinion on restaurants, but this place just doesn't cut it especially considering the price. You'd be much happier going to the buffet.

eNOqV0a81i3EqxLMo9NNrw.text: This review is quite late.. very late actually, but I remember my experience quite well since it was the night that Aria was only open for special guests, mainly friends and family of hotel execs, so everything was free... when I say everything, I MEAN everything. Table games and restaurants included.  Now about the restaurant. Plainly put, you'd be better off elsewhere. There is no creativity within their dishes, and they add nothing new to Vietnamese and south Asian cuisine, even though they are classified as a Pan-asian restaurant.  The only thing I enjoyed was their Tom Yum soup, which was traditionally made with natural,coconut juice and a foot portion of shrimp.  Pho restaurants off strip are much more delicious, and much less pricier.

E5YoRZ2fPQ0-rDlwRvRypA.text: We were staying at the Aria and I was craving for Asian food so we decided to try this place out instead of having to venture outside the hotel. It's supposed to be a Thai restaurant from what I understand but they have blended chinese fusion to it as well. I was surprised when I saw a Dimsum cart pull up next to our table but I was equally surprised by how authentic it all tasted. We ordered a good mix of thai and chinese dishes and were not disappointed. They say that you know it's a great Asian restaurant if you actually see Asian patrons in it and trust me, there was a fair number of us out there. The staff was friendly and attentive but the price is of course, was Vegas style, for something I feel I can get at a local joint for less money. Highly recommended for when you're looking for a great eats without having to leave the resort.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Entrance to the restaurant

SNpRvLuzEb7BTngZiSJYkA.text: The food was ok, but honestly nothing special.   Much better restaurants in the hotel.  Waiter was nice, but always seemed a bit to busy, so things ordered after the initial order to a while to get through.

o2QTmXCAwFmYODPJ4WYPcA.text: My favorite dish is the cashew chicken with a side of white rice. So flavorful and filling. A bit expensive but delivers a reasonable portion size. Ingredients: chicken, mushrooms, baby carrots, onions and cashews in a delicious light broth.

9ztPU_ZeF9WwJxOJvVZmEg.text: Staying at vdara when we saw lemongrass in the booklet in our room. Went to make a reservation on the open table app and nothing was immediately available. Took our chance and walked over since we were only a party of 2. They got us in right away and the restaurant was mostly empty so don't know why the open table app was booked. Got the pad Thai at 3 spicy. the dish was delicious, will definitely get 4 spicy next time as 3 wasn't as hot. Ordered the mango sticky rice and it was so delicious!! The mango was so sweet and soft! Can't wait to come back!

VZT7OlroBHEGNDlyFjvsJQ.text: I went to Lemon Grass during thanksgiving trip. Me and my wife are vegetarians. First we already had reservation, but they allowed us after 30 minutes. When we went inside, they were lot of empty spaces, not sure why it took them so long to allow us inside. Me and my wife ordered cocktails and apetizers. The apetizer we ordered was crispy tofu. We told them to bring cocktails first, but they bought apetizers, since we were really hungry, i had 2 peices and my wife had one piece. The taste was weird, the waiter was in the next table, we waited for him, we called him, the moment he looked our apetizer, he told it was seafood. At this point, i was really pissed off. The worst part was that he was totally unapologetic. I just lost my apetite for eating.  He was so casual as if its not a big thing, i beieve he was sure his restaurant is not going to be affected by people like me as there were lot of customers for them.  Ordered Vegetarian yellow currry and Fried rice. Yellow curry was really delicious but fried rice was really bland. Ordinary white rice would have worked here. The food quality was below average baring the yellow curry.

lc_V3EFUhU0W-HzSpsQ3Qw.text: A hidden gem of dining inside Aria. We stayed at Aria and the concierge helped us booked a reservation the last minute, and it was not a disappoint.  The ambient was great, very relaxing and calming.  For appetizer, we ordered the Chicken Satay, and for dinner we had the Pad Thai and Chilean Sea Bass. It was a great experience!  A must try.

rqKgz4Z53SZa3rXoxq0xdw.text: This place sucks and is overpriced. I had the pho and curry crab here and its literally disappointing.   The pho meat was dry (despite being in SOUP) while the broth was lukewarm and bland. Terrible terrible terrible.   The curry crab was pisspoor, using spice to cover up its utter lack of scrumptious taste. Clearly, the chef has never been to south east asia because the curry crab just tastes like salt and peppers. Word to the wise: when restaurants have zero flavor they over burden the food with salt. Lemongrass is one of these restaurants.   Avoid it unless its absolutely the last last last choice in the world. Unless of course you like terrible food.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The worst curry crab in the world. No curry. No crab. Wtf

w8-yUOYbVh3tlmf8ClWLCQ.text: Huge portion and accomodating service!  I came to Lemongrass for lunch during restaurant week in mid June. Overall, the food was pretty good and the service was great.   I had the 4 course specials for $30 and it includes satay appetizer, soup, choice of entree and mango sorbet dessert. I was pretty happy that they were able to change the beef satay to shrimp with only mininal increases in price. I ordered the noodle entree and the portion was huge. The mango sorbet was a nice refreshing dessert at the end.   The only thing I did not like was the tom yum soup with mushroom. It was extremely spicey (even for someone very used to spicey food). I had to drink a full glass of cold water in order to wash down half a bowl of soup.   Other than that, I was pretty happy with my meal.

9drt_mvsS1szGJQmQEOBTg.text: Great Foods!! Good service!! It is located inside the Caesar palace!! Can't ask for more!!

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fancy restaurant inside Aria

gHdubVFpWADHyqbcuWtF4A.text: Food was flavorless and served cold. Plates were not  picked up had to request to clear plates twice. Staff  should go next door with Blossom manager to get trained in service

AXX_cCmbsAhJ5zMAoNLOaw.text: Overpriced thai food!  I get it. The restaurant is in the Las Vegas strip, but if you are going to over charge the food should at least be good.  I love thai food, especially pad Thai and their version is bland and boring.  The yellow chicken curry is $18 and doesn't even come with rice. I can't imagine enjoying curry without rice so I shelled out the extra $3 bringing my curry dish to $21.  Dinner for 4 (without alcoholic beverages) was $120.  We each ordered 1 entree and split an appetizer for the table.  You can drive 10 minutes in any direction off the strip and get food that is 10 times better for literally 1/3 of the price.  The ambiance of the restaurant is ok. It is located in a quiet corner off the casino floor next to the high limit area. There is not a lot of people watching but t is a perfect spot if you want a quiet dinner or lunch.  The staff is ehh. No one is over friendly but they aren't rude either.  I have been a few times and we almost always have to wave down out server to let them know we are ready to pay.  To sum it up only go here for convenience.  If you are staying at the Aria or close by and don't feel like venturing outside of the hotel. Food is overpriced and bland but I did eat it.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Leftovers...

dqgTe4RsrK4tUeLSa35GHA.text: I had the beef pho and it was good. They gave me plenty of vegetables and meat, and their pork dim sum was delicious!

Rc9Ma--mZMCrHn-upAzuFA.text: After 3 long nights of Las Vegas madness, we were craving a little normalcy and quiet. Walking into Lemongrass gives you and immediate sense of relaxation and calm. It was exactly what we were looking for.  There's lots of space here. High ceilings, lots of space between tables and a sprawling layout. A few salads and dumplings started us off, then followed by the winner - hot and sour seafood soup. A huge bowl of satisfying lime broth filled with squid and shrimp, noodles and vegetables will give you all you need to recover from the hard living of this city.  Have some pad Thai noodles or basil chicken if you like. Have whatever you want - it's all good here.

KJyYoVlAl8iRKbMkOqgq-g.text: Waited about 15-20 minutes along with a few other parties in front of the hostess desk for the hostess to show up and seat us or at the very least take our names down but to our surprise, no one showed up nor acknowledged our presence.  There were tons of staff walking around and there was even a manager looking person towards the back who failed to even make his way to the front or find someone to assist the ever building crowd.  Never ever have I experienced anything like this.  If the restaurant was busy and packed, I would understand.  However, the place had multiple empty tables.  If this level of service is any representation of the restaurant, I can't even imagine how atrocious the food must taste.

OZb6ZdiyOPZyykcRrUKbtw.text: Overall very disappointed in their service. It took over an hour to get our food and the restaurant was not even full. Our waiter was changed halfway through our dining and he wasn't updated on our split checks. We had to ask for a manager to help get our food and no discount was offered nor did she check back up on us to make sure we were happy. Well, surprise we were not. We won't ever be going back again as we didn't even get all our food and some of it was wrong. The food itself was good hence the only reason I gave any stars.

6MUrPjKL0mKii6d28_sEww.text: Good food and drinks.  Slightly overpriced.  We did not have reservations and had a 40 min wait.  I would recommend reservations and/or sitting at the bar.

-hnvvvoy3IzjFRwV7tB__w.text: We went here for a team dinner, tried a lot of their dishes. Every item we tried was amazing and the prices were affordable.

j_zPqSjGcVjgI7VlZ5ycTw.text: Despite reading reviews I often go into a restaurant with an open mind because I'm conscience that everyone's taste is different.   Unfortunately I was quite disappointed (after ordering the Red Duck Curry)! Almost want to say that this was the worst Thai I've had. I remember recently saying to a friend I don't think there's a things such as "bad" Thai and I've been proven wrong tonight.   I often eat Thai food including northern and southern CA, New York, Canada, London, Paris and of course Thailand so I know a bit about Thai food. Ps I hardly ever write reviews but I felt compelled to write one, given that visiting Vegas where majority of restaurants are overpriced...I think it should be a guaranteed good and tasty meal!  Of almost forgot the Thai ice tea actually was good.

26Bb1sB6YtFbveTGmCvlYA.text: I've been going here for years and everything about this place is great. The pork neck and soft shell crab fried rice are our absolute favorite! And I love how late they stay open because this is where we end up after our long trip from California!

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork neck, pad Thai, pad de ew, and soft shell crab fried rice

ctzThf8Zmywa3FvlzxgWUg.text: This is the one place I have to go to when I get into Vegas for one thing and one thing only.  It is called Sampan Crab.  It is so amazing that my review will not do it justice!  We went here at 12:30am right after the New Year's Eve fireworks show on the Strip.  We had the spicy cucumber as an app.  It was really good and tasted like authentic Korean Kim Chee with sesame oil added to it.    The Red Curry with Beef was really good and tasted well when paired with the sticky rice.  But the Sampan Crab is the start of the night as it is every night.  This is by far the best Crab I have ever eaten in my life.  For $68 you get the head and a bunch of claws, arms, legs, body, etc.  The portion is so HUGE!    The crab is moist and delicate.  The breadcrumbs mixed with the peppers and gaclic just work.  You can scrape it off the shell and eat it.  Then work your way into the flesh and the combination has to be one of the best things I have ever tasted in my life.  The order easily feeds 2 people.  I would highly recommend that anyone in Vegas go down here and eat this dish.  Just make sure you save some for me when I go back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red Curry 紅咖哩 - Beef, Red curry, coconut milk, pineapple, Thai basil, bamboo shoots, Thai eggplant
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sampan Spicy Crab 避風塘炒蟹 - Live Dungeness crab, red chili, fried garlic, breadcrumbs
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Asian Cucumber 麻辣黃瓜 - Cucumber, chili-garlic, vinegar, sesame oil

iRFQ8jZw6o2VddBMUzLmTw.text: Average dim sum. If you've had dim sum elsewhere and enjoyed it, this place will probably not live up to it. The Shanghai dumplings were completely dry. WHAT??? The egg tarts were more like butter tarts and the steamed BBQ pork buns were really sweet.   We also ordered Pad See Ew and it turned out to be  pretty good. The noodles were good and not overcooked. The pot stickers also had good flavor. Lastly, we had the hot and sour soup. They're not kidding about it being hot. Not temperature hot but spicy hot. I really like spicy, but this was a wee too spicy.   The service was great. The man serving the dim sum was Chinese and could speak both Mandarin and Cantonese.

-HW7q15j-rr5EzTTv0F-Ig.text: Wonderful services & Calm n Relax ambiance   Ordered:  Papaya Salad, seasoned fried squid, and Pad Thai. Everything was very fresh and flavorful! Clean taste, perfect seasoning.  Love the decor here, so relax and comfortable, nice for a peaceful lunch out at busy Vegas strip:)

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Very nice presents of dishes:)
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States

DJHWMlG1F-FOALSI66vk3Q.text: Very tasty food but heavy. I recommend this place for lunch but not dinner as it sits on your stomach because of all of their spices. Nevertheless, very tasty. Pork neck is a favorite and I always get it when I visit ARIA. Brunch is always a good idea on the weekends.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States

J_3lXfDe7K5e2HSN1m7cmQ.text: Excellent food and service. Beautiful atmosphere. Try the satay and ribeye. Curries are wonderful as well.

btzbh7y8cSL_Ubc-g37e7A.text: Great food, cool atmosphere, great service! Given the ridiculously over-priced options in Las Vegas, this one was actually worth the price, and it wasn't totally over the top expensive.  Loved the chicken satay, Singapore noodles, and pepper beef udon noodles.

q_8l8vL07dqenwjqDlI8eA.text: Last Friday when we arrived in Vegas we were hungry and wanted to find a place to eat lunch.   We were staying at the Vdara and decided to walk across the way to Aria to see their restaurants and we decided to eat at Lemongrass.   We were immediately seated but the service got off to a slow start.   We sat at the table for almost 15 minutes before we were offered something to drink. I asked for water and he asked for beer (one the was on tap but I can't remember). It took almost 10 minutes for our drink orders and we placed our order once the drinks were brought to the table out of fear of the waitress disappearing and not returning.   This restaurant is very versatile and can accommodate groups, children or date nights if the service is up to par.   We ordered the spicy prawns and spicy Asian cucumbers for our appetizer. My husband ordered sesame chicken for his entree and I had the pla lobster salad.   The appetizers arrived fairly quickly and to our surprise the prawns were actually flattened a bit so that they can be rounded and looked like a panko coated crab cake. The prawns while a little different were absolutely delicious as was the rest of he food and the portions were fairly large.   There was celery in the salad that I had ordered and I was picking it out as I am not a big fan of celery. The waitress asked if my food was okay and I told her that it was very good and my husband chimed in that I was picking out the celery because I don't really like it.   The waitress offered to take my salad back an remake it without the celery which was very nice but I told her that it was no problem and that I would eat the salad that I was served. She seemed a bit concerned that I may not enjoy my meal and asked if I was sure and when I assured her that it was okay she left.   The waitress came back to the table about 10 minutes later and asked if I was ok again and if I was enjoying my salad and once again I assured her that the salad was delicious. I did appreciate her concern.   As we were eating another waitress was pushing a cart containing dim sum thru the dinning room. The food on the cart looked and smelled delicious but we didn't order any because we knew were not going to able to eat all of the food we had ordered.   The prices are a little steep especially since or bill was over $50 for lunch but hell we were in Vegas!

xMfzIfCCkSTB4Lpv-pePZQ.text: In a sea of overpriced, greasy, carb laden, sugary food, how nice to have a Tom kha coconut soup and yellow curry. Soup, papaya salad (too much fish sauce), and chicken curry with (yes) brown rice was $44. For a Thai place anywhere else, that's pricy. For Vegas, what a deal.

pA7tscqqN0hODNPakwal5g.text: Delicious! We were staying at Vdara and found this place walking around Aria and decided to make a reservation. We went with a large group and I think everyone liked their food. I ordered yellow curry and some wine, and both were tasty. For dessert we ordered the mango sticky rice, fried banana, and something with coconut (I can't remember what it was). All of those were awesome. The prices were also decent--I think my meal was ~$15 or so, but they had more expensive/fancy entrees if that's what you're into. The service was also super friendly and fast. We waited the perfect amount for our food--not too short (where you feel rushed and wonder if they even cooked your food) but not too long. Our waiter Chun was great. I'd definitely love to go here again, especially because I always get cravings for Thai food. It's good to know next time I get a craving in Vegas.

R7lwkmsF-vjQOfEYy__MKA.text: Visited here on a Sunday night right before the Cirque Du Soleil show upstairs (which was terrific!). The restaurant was not busy at all, so the reservation I made proved pointless. The decor was nice, but I didn't expect anything else from an establishment inside the Aria. My friend and I were very thirsty and the best thing about the staff was that they kept our waters filled the entire time! That was huge for us, and brought us back to life at the end of a long weekend in Vegas. We got the Salmon Spring Rolls as an appetizer and I am very glad we did. These were excellent! I had the Singapore Noodle as a main dish and this was also very good and sized appropriately for the price. I was a little worried that it wouldn't be enough food given how hungry I was, but everything worked out fine. At the end, I paid under $40 for an appetizer and main dish along with generous tip. I thought this was pretty good for Vegas, and the food quality was above average. I would go back if I was in the Aria, but it is a bit out of the way if you are just strolling the Strip since the restaurant is tucked in the back of the Casino. The dessert options here were poor, but do yourself a favor and visit the Gelato spot just down the hall, Jean Phillippe Patisserie. $5 will satisfy your sweet tooth with a generous cup of your flavor choosing!

e2fqU5tgy3U6vI0KXn-U7Q.text: Good as it gets!   Touristy americanized asian food in delisious little plate style, great items on the menu order everything, we did!

ptzDJcKSh2v8vhkn-NhtYA.text: Food was very good and service was awesome.  We ate here before a show and they served us super quick as requested.  Would definitely eat here again.

FguzcYKb5IdC6mrGtsoCxw.text: I really enjoyed the ambiance of this restaurant. It's secluded away from the gaming floor and really feels like it's on its own property. The Chicken Satay is a must. Can't wait to go back!

Y2KqOggvaVBWtjMRaGh6_w.text: Lemongrass is so beautiful when you walk in the chandlers are massive - the decor is very inviting... My friend and I dined here tonight... The food was good - I had the egg rolls and a sauteed vegetables w/ rice  sake was very good... My friend had a chicken and beef skewers w/ rice... They are a little pricey for what we had... I could of went to china a go go and got enough to feed 5 ppl... but the customer service was A+

ob9JhTe-keK8d9deAxnn7A.text: stumbling in at around 2am - it's one of the few places to eat late night at Aria without having to leave the casino. we were warmly greeted at the door and quickly sat as they were closing in about an hour or so. there was about 4 other tables already dining.  upon being sat - we flipped thru the menu - everything sounded good and reasonably priced (except for a few lobster dished running well over $100). 10 minutes had now passed and we haven't been acknowledged or asked if we were ready or needed water. my buddy began to dose off - as i attempted to wave someone down but there was only two chinese guys cleaning the same table on the other side of the restaurant. another 10 minutes passed before a waiter walked by only to clean the table next to us before i was able to get his attention to take our order.  we ordered seafood stir fry, seasame chicken, wonton noodle soup and crispy chicken wings. food was brought out as they came and so was two glasses of water. call me fickle - BUT - for a fine establishment at Aria - i would have expected to either be asked - and if not - appetizer being brought out before anything else. futhermore - i shouldn't have to ask for more water multiple times, esp when there was only two tables left. when i'm at a fancy restaurant - attention to detail is a must! i only ate the wonton and chicken wings (as that was my order) - the chicken wings were good. great crispy texture and juicy meat - tasted even better with the thai chili sauce it came with. the wonton noodle soup on the other hand was nothing to rave about. very sub par. borderline bland. mid way thru eating - the check was dropped off and asked if we can pay right away as the cashier is going to go home. so not only did we have to wait for their services - we had to rush ourselves.  not impressed by any means.

nXiyBttI7Aillxwihyq_sg.text: Not bad! Really good fried rice with seafood I forgot which one, the one without the pork for sure. I like their orange chicken. They have dim sum and other Asian food there'd too not just thai. I would come back..

5YP3-iecoNB-rAnL7rgiAA.text: We stopped by for a late dinner and were promptly seated and served.  All of the food and drinks were on point, but it was very pricey for a Thai meal.

GDbO1KNv4U_u0ICoQ3z20g.text: I live in Portland, Oregon, a place that boasts a Thai restaurant every block. This place was fantastic...we had the yellow curry (sub tofu for chicken) and the pad see ew. Everything was fantastic. Some of the best Thai food I've had in quite a while.

aQ9UwHViAS6zOOm2XKPlUw.text: I really enjoyed Lemongrass..Service was great, food was amazing.  The quality of the food was excellent and I personally don't think it was expensive at all - comparing what you receive.  If you are looking for a good thai food this is the place to go!

qnWqh3juno05mmrvr7cJ2Q.text: It is with great regret that I have to give Lemongrass only 2 stars.  This resto nails the sexy asian vibe, with its stunning minimalist decor.  Service is also v. good -- with folks coming in to check up on diners at regular intervals.  But, no amount of service and decor can make up for so-so food.... Now, I can try to blame it on one of my dining companions, who insisted that the spice factor for all the dishes be a 1 on scale of 10.... but, non-spicy food can still have flavor.  While the salmon spring rolls had a nice crisp to them, throughout the rest of the meal (which included shrimp fried rice, steamed cod, cashew chicken and tiger prawns), I kept thinking: this is dressed up Panda Express.... in a tuxedo.  Seriously. Entrees at over $25 for sub-par food?? Nope.  Never again.  Hopefully, food gets better soon...

dhNBHpiw942K5VMmW5tnhA.text: Very nice wait staff.  Good food and quick service.  We ordered take out so we can enjoy it in our hotel room.  Very nice ambiance too.

fdnSDUg9U_pb_CChnipzfA.text: Hands down the best fried calamari I've ever had, the other dishes were fantastic as well. Great value for the money, 3 entrees, 2 appetizers, 2 cocktails $100 the Thai tea cocktail was worth mentioning as well

tVJRrcC6S_iG0EPrcR_i2w.text: I have been to various Thai restaurants and hole in the walls are better than this place. Their food is greasy! I expected this place to serve good Thai food being in a casino, but was I wrong. If you go, just bring a bottle of Tums and you are set. I give 2 stars vs. 1 because their Thai iced tea was delicious :-)

cOnA2VeCc4w8NXgpFHG3tw.text: This was a last minute choice with local friends. Very good food but we each ordered an entree. We should have shared.

tp8Jd4UTtnFUkxl35zdvCQ.text: good food, good service, reasonable price! can't complain! they sat us and came to help us very quickly. the drinks and refills came without asking, the food came without us having to wonder when we will get our food, and they didn't rush us and was very nice about everything! amazing!

mcF9ioIBBjg40eOpA3cRGA.text: Reserved at lemongrass for a party of 10. After 2 days and nights of partying it was time for a recharge.  From the start we were treated like kings. We asked for some chef's recommendations and were regaled with all kinds of deliciousness. The bass, the satay, the pad thai, and the soups were especially fantastic. We kept ordering and ordering until no one could eat any more... and the bill was surprisingly low! We had a great time, service was fantastic, and they did a great job accommodating a large group. Highly recommend.

g6DnZZT7FoLIu931KDO5pQ.text: What a nice place to eat at! Came here by recommendation and paying it forward. Decor matched the restaurant theme perfectly. Appetizers were good. For my main dish, I had the Curry Dungeness Crab at a level 7 (1-10 spicy). I was sweating a bit, but enjoyed it so much! Dish was huge and overall experience great. I go back there every time I am in Vegas!

1-12p53hbnsP_N8tbpmTqw.text: Very representative of the situation my wife and I often find ourselves in: it is hard to find good food on vacation. Lemongrass offers classically mediocre Thai food, plus you will get a 1 hour wait for absolutely no reason. Our meal: fried spring rolls ($10) these were clearly straight out of the freezer, no flavor, soggy vegetables; pho reeked of cinnamon ($15); Singapore Noodles Stir-fried rice vermicelli, BBQ pork, shrimp, onion, bean sprouts, bell pepper, egg, curry powder ($18) this was quite good and very spicy, earning Lemongrass 3 instead of 2 stars.  Poor food, poor service, long wait. Do not make a reservation; I would suggest trying a different restaurant.

MT6f931-YNfFPZGcVt0ShQ.text: Went to Lemongrass for the 1st time. It was pretty good. Had the sesame chicken, fried prawns and pad see ew noodles.   The sesame chicken was ok. I was expecting better quality because Lemongrass is a nice upscale restaurant in an upscale hotel. Not bad but not great.   The fried prawns on the other hand were really good. Good size and portion. The pad see ew noodles were good as well. Not a big fan of flat noodles but these were tasty  I would definitely recommend Lemongrass to anyone looking for good Thai food. I will be heading back to try the other options they have.

UyYwIUPb7boKudm8_O-Odg.text: If you want cheap amazing Thai food, go to Noodle House off the strip in Chinatown. If you want overpriced mediocre Thai food, you've found it at Lemongrass. After waiting 45 minutes to sit down even though they had open seats inside I got the Pad See Ew.  Didn't have very much flavor and was disappointing.

dJV1SQWUwaF-PZqvBhGewQ.text: It's amazing how you can go to the same restaurant twice and have two completely opposite experiences, one a 5 star and one a 1 star.  We went today at 2:30 pm to eat after an INCREDIBLE experience 11pm Saturday night. Saturday night it was fairly empty, and we sat at the bar. A great female bartender took our order, took care of everything with my food allergies, and was overall awesome. The food itself was delicious.   Today, the food was AWFUL. The service by a bartender again (Shawn) was horrible. He was obviously stressed and not only served us badly (screwed up the order, didn't send my cold app out with my husband's hot app), but didn't even provide silverware or napkins for the people next to us. My order was wrong (I didn't say anything, it wouldn't have gotten me anywhere), and the food runners didn't even seem to know where the food was going and just asked the patrons who ordered chicken satay.   If you're going to come here, recognize that it's totally hit or miss.

nb8LQwkIdO7N-oECJKB-BA.text: Wanted something quick and this recommended we order the chicken wings and the Phad See Ew with chicken. The chicken wings were ok and the Phad See Ew had no flavor at all. Very disappointing considering the price point of the meals.

o7l01PBhL2fs_5LB2a99hA.text: Yum yum everything is good. Expensive Thai but it's Vegas so what do you expect. But the best thing is the superb and attentive service!!!

ii5zO1QPJAqjLeVGnSLHnw.text: my dad wanted to try this place out, so we decided to go. the decor is nice, unlike the food..  I ordered the roasted duck and bbq pork noodles, and I was very disappointed. the only thing good about it was the pork. the duck had too many bones and barely any meat, the soup was very oily and lacked flavor, the vegtables weren't cooked all the way, and neither were the noodles. my dad ordered pad thai. he told them no peanuts but they still put some on the plate. the server was nice enough to go fix that. other than that, my dad said the pad thai was okay, nothing special.  I decided to give the place another chance. I ordered pad kee mao spicy 4/10. I'm not sure how they measure their spicy level, but I did say 4/10, which shouldn't be all that spicy.. but it was. I couldn't enjoy it because my tongue was burning. but there was so much wrong with this, I don't even.. ok, so aside from the spiciness, the meat and especially the vegtables were inconsistently cut. majority of the pieces were very big as well as very undercooked. another thing was that the noodles were hardly seperated; most of the noodles were still stuck together. lastly, there was so much basil.. again, aside from it being not cooked properly, there was so much that I had it in every bite, it was overpowering. that being said, I would not come here again, and I would definitely not recommend this place to anyone. it's just bad food for an expensive price.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. way too much basil, I had it in every bite
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. noodles were not seperated, stuck together
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. vegtables were undercooked and cuts were too big

ekDLWMwpOEoAkQpmzFW87A.text: I would consider this Westernized Thai and would not have selected to eat here but.. 1. It was our first night in Vegas 2. It was getting late 3. We were all hungry 4. We needed a place to round up the troops 5. We had to get ready and head out to the club ASAP  eating just before 10pm, the place was still pretty packed and we waited for about 15 minutes before a table for 15 opened up. The waitress who seemed very nice in the beginning eventually became more grumpy throughout the night.  A variety of dishes were ordered to share, family style. Between my few friends who opted for this suggestion, we got a singapore style noodle with peppers, shrimp and the works. It was tasty, good filling and nice fusion-like flavours. To try something different, we got a chicken hot pot, which was cooked beautifully. It had spice and kick to it, while the chicken was saucy and tender. Piping hot, this was my favourite. A staple dish that I use to order when available was pineapple fried rice. Usually at the "hole in the walls," the rice was actually served in a half of a pineapple and little bits can be scraped out at the end. However, this was just served on a plate and the worse pineapple fried rice I've ever tasted - no joke. The rice was dry and burnt. There was lack of flavours and just hard to eat. I tried to consume more of the other dishes to satisfy my hunger instead.  The prices seemed reasonable, with some lobster delicacies as high as $110. Not sure if it would be worth it.

rf7NQFNgjcsN-weQyG-v_w.text: Was greeted and seated promptly.  Didn't know dim sum was served here, so we were pleasantly surprised to see the dim sum on wheel carts while following the hostess to our table.  (Today is Sunday, so I am not sure if dim sum is available on just Sundays, on both Saturday and Sunday, or every day).  The staff is very attentive and friendly.  The suggestions our waitress recommended were on point.  Well, except for the papaya salad, which lacked the kick that most papaya salads have.  Barely tasted the fish sauce or lime in it.     Loved the sea bass, the marinated fried squid.  If you're in the Aria and you're craving Asian / Thai'ish (yes, I said "ish") food, Lemongrass is definitely worth checking out.  Pricing is also reasonable.  My party of 3 ate 4 selections of dim sum, sea bass, marinated fried squid, papaya salad, brown rice, and we also drank 2 Thai teas and 1 fresh-cocunut juice for a total of $103 pre-tip.  More importantly, we were FULL AND SATISFIED.  Worth coming back to try out more of what their menu offers.

WywCjveV5qwZBUeh7C7vTA.text: I haven't felt this sexy in a long time.  A group of seven of us dressed to the nines and showed up at Lemongrass.  First off, the Aria on its own is a beautiful casino and a great alternative on the North Side of the strip as opposed to the rundown hustle and bustle of Freemont Street hotels.  Secondly, the Lemongrass restaurant was probably the best Thai Food I ever had.  I ordered a level 7, which was at the time I mistake.  But the curry was so good that I kept eating it, mouth burning, and a Sapporo to wash it down, that by the time I realized I was too full to eat anymore, I couldn't stop shoveling it in my mouth!  Yes.  Shoveling.  I'm not the kind of girl you can take to eat in public.  lol.  The server was friendly and he got all of our orders perfectly correct.  The kinds of places I usually eat, one has to worry about that kind of thing often in a big group.  The total bill was something like $250, for the seven of us.  We all ordered an entree and a beverage or two.  Because it was our friend's birthday, she got any drinks she ordered comp'd.  That was nice of the waiter!  I can picture myself eating here again next time Vegas calls my name.  Heck, I could even picture myself staying at the Aria.

Xx9UGN8mzyn1KTARYkXslg.text: If you're at the Aria, swing by Lemongrass for some Thai food that will leave you stuffed and absolutely overjoyed.  The atmosphere is chic and idyllic for a night out.  Snag yourself a booth and admire the decor that might just be unlike anything you've ever seen before.  If you're a little unsure of what to order or a first-timer, you can't go wrong with the Sweet and Sour Chicken.  It's classic, but so good that you'll finish the entire dish in one sitting.  It's tangy and sweet, breaded, and dashed with a little pineapple, bell pepper, and onion.  Do yourself a favor and dine out there more than once!

qiG_CsPZyUjY0DrE_HTMvg.text: Chicken satay - pretty good. The mee goreng is not authentic indonesian, it has tomato ketchup sauce. The pas see ew was good but rather salty as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sticky rice with mango
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mee goreng
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Satay chicken

u7fVAqJ1uWskzJum4N-2dw.text: After visiting a buffet 3 times during my stay in Vegas (Aria twice and Caesar's once, Bacchanal Buffet) a decision was reached to try a sit down restaurant to quench the Thai food craving. We had passed this place a couple of times while roaming around Aria so we decided to give it a try.     We were seated promptly and our drink orders were taken. I ordered the Drunken Noodles with Seafood (spice level 4) and my compatriot ordered the Basil Meat with Shrimp (spice level 5) with jasmine rice. The food here is meant to share as medium sized plates are already on the table and they the meals/food ordered is brought in larger plates. I have never had drunken noodles before so I cannot compare it to other dishes I've had, but it was delicious. The noodles were the right thickness to absorb the delicious sauce and there was an ample amount of seafood (4 medium sized scallops, 4 shrimp, and 3 pieces of calamari). The basil meat with shrimp was fresh and had good flavor to it. We also ordered extra spice on the side so that we could control the spice level (can order level 1-10), but we did not add any additional spice to our meal beyond the level that we ordered.     I would definitely come back again to Lemongrass to try the other dishes on the menu as this visit was a delicious hit.

hMCLQGH6g1PRXz8WiT1d9g.text: Three others and myself arrived at around 9 pm. We were seated with no reservation after 5 minutes. Ambience is pretty, it was nice and dimly lit. We waited over 10 minutes for our server, Cheng, to come to our table. While he was pleasant, he seemed a little shy and disappeared for most of our meal. The menu wasn't explained to us, nor did he help at all in making suggestions. He was only there to take our drink and food order and drop off dessert at the end. Also, we could barely hear his quiet voice. I appreciated all of the other bussers refilling our water glasses and picking up our finished plates, however.  The food was delicious! The grilled pork neck was the highlight of our meal. Very tender and flavorful. Also, the iceberg dessert was very unique. I loved the corn and rose water flavor, it was delicious.   I don't think I would come back. Service is part of a dining experience, and tonight's service left me feeling frustrated. But two stars for ambience and food.

D1ytr5ifTk_s2Xb7vwV5iQ.text: Over priced and rude waitresses.... Entrees don't come with rice- $3 for a side of white/ $4 for brown rice.. Who eats curry without rice? I gave 2 stars because the pad Thai was good... But everything else was pretty bad! I Will not go again.

jHrmidbXo9F7pMv0tYwq7g.text: One of my favorite restaurants in Aria and one of the best Thai Restaurants on the Strip! Great service, great food, great prices, too. Lemongrass is open until fairly late, which is awesome for Las Vegas. I suggest trying their curries and Singapore noodles - those taste amazing!

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mango &amp; sticky rice

8TSFJuFOVkDf3rsDyFLWyQ.text: They deserve a wow!!! Everything was great, food quality, service, ambiance, price...100% recommended!!!

wlIirKnKhpEnmr9WvsutjA.text: Food- Tom yum soup is good - spicy and sour just the way I like it Red curry pretty good too Pork neck meat is delicious, tender and juicy  Service- we ordered takeout so don't know about the service there, but they will call to your room and tell you how long it will take,which is pretty nice   Overall, surprised Law Vegas has such a nice Thai food restaurant , definitely would recommend to everyone

-SnbwfJIxaybJQcMk4iTIw.text: Typical Las Vegas.  Food mediocre at best.  Not really Thai but more of a mixture of Asian cuisine.  Just an ok option for late night dining.   Service..... awful.  First off the hostess seats us at a dirty table with literally sticky sauce she clearly sees and proceeds to let me clean it because moving us to one of the 25 empty tables is too much to ask. Oh but she did offer me an extra napkin since I had to use mine to clean the table. The restaurant was maybe 1/3 full but the waitstaff was MIA for some time when a young man came to our table and told us our waitress was busy so he can take our order.  Once he took our order it was quite some time before we got our drinks, just a soda but flat. The next time we saw him we told him the sofa was flat and he offered to get us something else but I asked if they could just replace the co2 but he literally said no. Ok fine.  Then it took about another 20 minutes to get our appetizers and even longer for our meal.   The food... eh. Very lacking in flavor and I would not recommend eating chicken since both things we ordered had a very rubbery weird version of chicken.   I would not recommend this place at all.  We paid about $90 for 2 dishes and 2 appetizers. Waste of money.

zJrHgg1dFTC-EupGWwRQxA.text: Came here during the last day of our Vegas trip. The food was ok. I've had better Thai food but definitely pricey which was expected since it's located inside Aria casino. The Tom yum soup was my favorite and the portion was enough to share for 2-3 people. I was pretty surprised on the portion of the soup. I was expecting it to be individual size but it came out to be enough for 3.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried banana with ice cream
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pineapple fried rice
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red curry with duck

9mFLHvt53zpglY96HJCIgQ.text: Skip this place.  My expectations for this place were pretty low, but it was even worse than I thought. Tasteless shrimp appetizer followed by fish sticks (they called it sea bass). I sent the fish back because they had assured me it wasn't battered when I ordered it. The good news is they took it back no problem, the bad news is that the replacement, Thai basil, was just ok. Can get better version of this dish from any local Thai joint for half the price.

uRIqkxwbZtlZyoGn3Ji-Kw.text: They should rename this restaurant Lemontrash. The bad experience at this restaurant located in the beautiful and classy (besides Lemongrass) Aria hotel and casino started with the hostess. Not a pleasant attitude and a stink face. Then we were seated and our waitress seemed to be a unhappy person. Then the food - ordered dim sum. I'm a dim sum aficionado; and what I had at Lemongrass was old food in my opinion. Men lie, women lie, taste buds don't.   If you're thinking of patronizing Lemongrass in the Aria hotel and casino, I would recommend you don't unless your hobby is throwing away money.   To the Aria hotel and casino: why do you allow this subpar restaurant to be on the premises of your business and bring down your reputation? I've tried several of the restaurants at your hotel /casino and they've all been at an acceptable level of excellence, besides of course Lemongrass. (And the stay at your hotel has been solid and I've had fun at the tables and slot machines there too.) Perhaps it would be wise to tell the owner /management of this restaurant to shape up or ship out, in my opinion. Lemongrass is the bad apple at the Aria.

FqjM1VtTrUR2Hzm83DAUVA.text: Lemon Grass is located at Aria and towards to the back of the casino.  I got food credit while I staying at Aria, therefore, I picked Lemon Grass for lunch in order to spend the credit.  For additional bonus, I booked via open table to get 100 points.  At upscale restaurant in Vegas, we did expect the quality food but not authentic Thai food! After we checked out the menu, we found half of dishes were served Asian food (Chinese or Northern Chinese food) rather than Thai food.  I ordered green curry chicken and it tasted good. The chicken was tender and green curry sauce quite creamy but taste light not spicy at all. Honestly, most of Thai restaurants in Vancouver can make this simple dish.  My gal friend had beef brisket noodles and just average! The beef brisket a bit dry and chewy and the noodles were soft. Of coz, we were not expect any Asian food wouldn't be better in Vancouver or in Hong Kong.  Anyway, prices were reasonable for the quality and amount of food served. Especially we got free food credit for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef brisket noodles
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Green curry chicken
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States

cAIwIJTHJJFfErj8pb5FBQ.text: Authentic thai food on the strip. They have good vegetarian options too but then can pull out meat from almost any dish you pick, if you are a vegetarian. Their red curry is a must try! Most thai restaurants serve steamed rice with curry but this one doesn't! They'll charge you for serving steamed rice with the curry. The service is a little slow but I guess you can do away with this slight drawback for the yummy food they serve and pretty ambiance.

iR7jN3YB5IYHKMRdZxqyJQ.text: I was staying at the aria for a friends birthday and came across this dim sum restaurant that looked amazing. I was not disappointed. We made a reservation for noon and I started with the watermelon caipiro that was delicious! We then tried the sui mai, har gow and the scallop dumpling. All were very good. The prawn rolls are a great choice for an appetizer. We then decided to try their signature menu! The tom yum favored soup was one of my favorite items there. We had it extra spicy and it was just bursting with flavors. The ribeye was exceptional. It had a great smokey taste to it. We then finished off the meal with a fried banana with ice cream dessert. Everything was delicious and we will back back next time we are in vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our final bill
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BdaM0yKiV4hzonlOEdQa1A.text: We really enjoyed this restaurant. Even though it is in the Aria and on the Strip the prices were very reasonable and the food was excellent.  We started with Chicken Satay and Shrimp Rolls both were excellent.  For our entree I had the Papaya Salad and hubby had the Pho.  Both were seasoned well and very tasty.  We were a little disappointed when they didn't have Prik Nam Pla, a chili and fish sauce condiment, but the waitress was very accommodating and had the kitchen staff make us some.  No Thai dish is really complete without it and if you haven't tried it you really should.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp Rolls
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Satay
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef Pho

sfgsKO-ZzOt6T5OSQOw7mQ.text: This place is absolutely amazing. The staff is wonderful , our drinks never ran out , even waiters from other tables made sure our drinks were good. I ordered curry and I have to say that was the best curry I have ever had in my life. I will definitely come back next time I am in Vegas

DHoE4Kctl6NeeDgpXNL9HQ.text: Lemongrass has beautiful decor and is nicely situated amidst the Aria Hotel directly near the Sky Suites entrance. The restaurant is actually tastefully done with a central bar and plenty of tables. The food itself is nothing short of average, it isn't terrible but it is by no means terrific. The Satay is essentially the best thing on the menu and you have your choice of meat, I've had the lobster and the beef, both were pretty good. The Phad See Ew with pork wasn't anything to write home about and the overall portion/presentation is simply just average as well. I will say that the Thai ice tea is pretty tasty...
