dEbm-sd7ujGYy_h5PurHvw.text: I really enjoyed that they had dim sum on the weekend. Not the best but not too bad.. Their pad Thai is really delicious and their yellow curry as well.. I came here a couple months before and their portions got a little bigger..

J8JHRQH-62e-92Drq1TMlw.text: Its laughable that they call it "authentic" because its not! it was completely dumbed down for people with no pallate. There were no spices. The curry was absolutely drab, like milky water. The soups should make your nose drip- nothing.  The pad thai, not hard to do, was a pile of wet noodles.   A beautiful venue for sure, but the food is bland.   Nice plating.   Go to Lotus of Siam if you want real Thia food.

w5eqY36Bqh3E3FTsutINgQ.text: We came here around 1am and split the pad Thai with shrimp. You can choose the spice level from a 1-10. We got a 1 because I was hesitant about the spice level concept, but it was still delicious. Great late night dining. I enjoyed it better than the Aria Cafe.

DlGv_31LNY1cR1ZC1VvzMw.text: This would usually be a 5 star review, as I have been here many times. However, this last visit was less than good. The yellow curry came out far to spicy despite saying spicy level 2. When I asked the dish to be remade the waiter was less that kind and tried to tell me there was no spice in the dish. I can handle spicy. In fact I usually order spicy 7. On this particular evening it was late and I was not into spicy. I would still recommend trying it out. This was my first off experience in six times eating there.

UTeFOEcl6MvMv15E4Uw8hw.text: Good Thai food here, just not authentic in my eyes.  The Salmon egg rolls were AMAZING though, and I'd highly recommend the watermenlon caeproskra (?). Delicious!  Pad thai was so-so. Not authentic whatsoever. But I'd go back and try some other dishes.  Service was great also!

6Z2lAAbnh6ClOsg8G_JduA.text: Ambience was quite nice and food was "OK" but not worth the $$$ prices. Watch out for there Prik Nam Plah....it's killer!!!  All was not lost as they had Fever Tree tonic for my Hendricks Gin!

bzm_LsY1MwwtKs0rvDtwqw.text: Very bland but I think they do this to accommodate every pallet on the planet. (Had the same experience at Noodle no 9 at Caesars). Had beef pad se ewe and it was blank. Had to pile on soy sauce and sriracha to get any flavor out of my meal. Ordered Chicken satay as an app and my gf had cashew chicken. The chicken satay was good. Crisp but tender and served on a skewer adored to a pineapple hunk. Peanut sauce was as expected and the cucumber relish was a little different tasting. Lighter and not nearly as bitter. The cashew chicken was fail

NwKkag5lFAGi2okAZPBjAg.text: This was a last resort for a late night bite anywhere besides bar food. The lights are dim and the vibe is more romantic than family style. Salmon eggrolls for appetizer are very different, but very delicious! We ordered the ribeye- which had good flavor but half of it was completely all fat and the other half was extremely thin for a ribeye. We also got the Pad Thai with chicken with a "Thailand Hot" flavor 4 out of 10 and it was very good! Service was good as well. We would eat here again.

XWqNGZrrBk4CqbJK0E2Z5w.text: Tried to book a table on OpenTable but it appeared to be sold out, so my husband asked to just call them and find out if there was an availability. And voila!....so, I don't really know whether to trust OpenTable or not anymore...  We were seated immediately upon arrival. Lovely ambience, very lounge like.  Had the tom kah and chicken satay (full marks for their peanut saurce) for appetizers, both really good.   For the Entree, I had the Crab Fried Rice, along with Green Curry, and Black pepper shrimp. I simply loved the fried rice, the crab meat was so tender and juicy.  The black pepper sauce was beautifully done, and the consistency was perfect to be paired with the rice.  For dessert, we shared the Sticky rice with Mango. One word YUMM! Although, in some other places, the sticky rice is black jasmine rice which somehow makes it all the more appealing. Still, this dessert did a good job.   Great value for the price if you're looking for a slightly more reasonable dinner tab.

u_7yCjBSZiFcxMFyr9bkfA.text: The best meal I had on that Vegas trip. Our flight home was cancelled, after sitting on the plane for two hours being told a bunch of crap. Couldn't fly out til the next morning. We had been staying at Aria, and arranged to come back and stay one more night, with a nice discount. We were starving, and hadn't eaten there yet. The food was AMAZING. My husband and I love Thai food and eat it often, always down to try new places. This is the best Thai food I've ever had. I took my mom back during her birthday trip and she loved it too. It's decor is beautiful, the service is good, and the prices for the quantity and quality are very good. It's kinda high end but relaxed.

5qg0RWXblT8CYYPnbxw-jQ.text: What a fun evening we had at Lemongrass to celebrate my 65th birthday!  All four of us had the sampler menu with the wine pairings.  Timing was off at the beginning but once that was corrected we had a delicious dinner.  Our waitress, Angela Collette Moran was a gem and that is why the four stars.  As it turned out her daughter's birthday was the same day as mine and my granddaughters!!  Birthday buddies all around

bTpfSTnW0-K_U1-Ketz5QA.text: Pretty tasty!  We got food here twice during our Vegas stay.  The first time we dined in.  We got the tom kha chicken, as well as the panang curry beef.  The tom kha was pretty fantastic, but the curry was just meh.  I can't really put my finger on it, but it just didn't taste..authentic.  Our main gripe with the restaurant was the service.  It took FOREVER to go get our bill settled.  Our order was literally just the tom kha and panang.  To just ask for the bill, it took over 15 minutes. We put our card in the weird card holder boxes they had, and then....nothing.  At this point our waiter must've been kidnapped or roofied or something because he was nowhere to be seen.  Eventually, the boyfriend had to get up and walk directly to the check stand to drop off our card, just to get someone to process our payment info and get us the heck out of there.  From there, it took another 10 minutes for them to bring us our final receipt and return our card.  This was on a slow Tuesday night when there were maybe three other tables there.      The second time we ate here during our stay, we got our food to go.  This experience was much more positive.  The girl at the front who took our order was super helpful and friendly, and showed us how to charge the food to our MLife account.  This time we got the lobster satay and it was absolutely AMAZING.  The sauce was delicious and fresh, and the lobster was cooked perfectly.  We'd definitely return here just for that, but would probably get it to go just because of the dine-in service deficiencies.  I'd recommend the tom kha and satay here, but I'd definitely advise others to budget the time for the uber slow service.

VcZa0nySwSDauEImP1Atng.text: I honestly love this place. The staff is great and so is the food. I come here often and every time I make a reservation the service never fails. I definitely recommend eating here. For the price of everything you get huge plates.

AsQNxOyKjS5xQU2sikoJVw.text: Lovely atmosphere. Wait staff very friendly and attentive. I started with Thai basil soup and it was absolutely delicious!! For my entree I had beef chow fun and I wasn't disappointed. It was very tasty. Now will you excuse me I am slipping into a food coma!

ztqj4dE69zyyXTEr55-_Ig.text: As an asian person, the chicken pad thai was disappointing. so sour, over sauced, and small portions. the waitress was very nice. the price and the food was bad that's all. ambiance is nice, good service... better places to eat in las vegas than here.

yYU8hROAZXlM91KrdrsGVQ.text: Lemongrass It's not real Thi food.. Even not Chinese food.. Never n ever want to come again.. If you already tried thi food before .. You'll know it's really bad........

Rb7U9IyXrJ7buFh4N_eq4g.text: Finding decent Thai food in a hotel is a bit of a surprise. Wonderful coconut sauce, crisp, fresh vegetables. Nicely seasoned. More expensive than a local place, but you are in a casino. Given the other dining choices in the Aria, dollar for dollar, this is a great choice.

UPiV_cpq4K9jH3vmXdxgAg.text: Food was good and I thought the prices for a restaurant in a very nice hotel like the Aria were reasonable.  I had a problem with the service however.  We ordered 2 appetizers,  lobster soup, 4 entrees.  I specifically asked the server that they bring the food in the order I show above.  Appetizers came and we finished them, they cleared the table and then the soup and all the entrees showed up.  The soup takes time to serve and eat and by the time you're finished then the entrees aren't as hot as you would like.  A nice place like this should know better.  I was PO'ed at their mistake and at myself for not sending the entrees back.  I made sure the server knew I wasn't happy but he only apologized but did not offer desserts for the 4 of us or to reduce the bill.  I won't return.

85753-Gt36ujh7rhnkDtNQ.text: Great ambiance, very nice upscale thai food. I was comfortable having a late night bite there by myself at the bar.    As a single female business traveler, that's always a plus.

0jPNwWYuOi9O3imbNEMfaA.text: Arrived in vegas at 9pm, sort of too late to start a buffet, so my bf and I decided to stop by here since it's open till late.  Really nice decor and very good service.  However, it was verrrry pricey for basic thai food.  My bf ordered the drunken noodles with seafood for $20 and I ordered some sort of basil chicken rice or something for $15.  After tips and tax, it came out to almost $45 (and to think that a lunch buffet  at bellagio only cost us around the same price, it was a killer).    Not sure if it's because we were both sort of starving, but the food was pretty good.  But with that ticket price, it's only A-OK!

fnTaS_XPwBNKPQpZYQe4Gw.text: This is very unusual for me to not like a restaurant this much, I swear!  However this was such a disappointment, that it will be some time before I feel the need to go try another restaurant at Aria.  Especially since this the second time dinning there and both places have been mediocre at best. I will take some of the responsibility though, for having a bad experience, because we we're in a rush to get something to eat before Viva Elvis.  I had quickly searched before we left the house just to get an idea of what type of restaurants there was to choose from.  Being that me and my fiance visit Thailand at least once, every year, we really love Thai food.  Therefore, I was excited to try this place, eager to replace my last memory of the English pub that wasn't exactly delicious.   We started off on a bad foot, I admit, by being in such a hurry and it only got worse from there.  I had to basically argue with the waitress on how spicy I wanted my food.  I know I'm a round eye, but what kind of scale goes from 1-10 with 2-3 being medium, huh?  We always order around a level 7 at all our neighborhood Thai places and it comes out perfect.  So after a few minutes of bantering back and forth with the waitress, I finally get to a level 5 on our papaya salad and curry.    When I ordered peppermint hot tea with the food, instead of earlier when she came for the drink order, the look I received spelled trouble.  They served green tea, instead of peppermint, and then it took quite awhile to finally wave someone down so I could get it fixed.  Then the food came out.....Ugh! The papaya salad was seriously the worst I have ever had!  Not spicy at all and seemed to be missing an ingredient.  The curry was also very bland and thank goodness I decided we need some veggies at the last minute because they were really the only good thing we ordered.    The street vendors in Thailand could definitely teach these cooks a thing or two.   Like I said, I hate focusing on the negative, but save your money and go to a small neighborhood Thai place like Jasmine or Archie's, where the food will be authentic and the service friendly!

tNCzNzB2a9drGr0regwCbw.text: Absolute A! Lemongrass is a definite favorite. The ambience and location make it perfect for a family dinner or night out with friends. The food is really amazing! I always love the soups and the pad-see-ew. The fried rice was kind of off, as it came covered in this liquidy sauce but we asked the waiters to bring out a new one, prepared more traditionally which was great. However, it was an interesting taste if you would like to try. Our first waiter was a little snobbish which was annoying but the waiter working our table was a delight so that is definitely not a reason to pass up on this amazing restaurant. If you're in the mood for thai food in an elegant setting, I recommend Lemongrass for sure! Hope you enjoy

zjt_VaqqsrrzSOoXKP6pUA.text: The menu here was very standard American Thai -- nothing out-of-the-ordinary. You've got your Pad Thai, some various noodle dishes, some soups, a few curries, and so forth. Some were dressed up a bit (lobster in the Tom Yum soup), but it was basically a standard menu.  But it was as fresh and clean and well-prepared as any Thai food I've had. Flavors were right-on. The soup was perfectly balanced (cool + hot). My shrimp were nicely crusted. There was a bit too much syrupy sauce on one tofu stir fry dish for my liking, but that was the only loser.  The restaurant is a little hidden in the Aria, and both times we went there was no wait. The price is about the same as the buffet upstairs (which can have long lines!), but the food is definitely a notch higher.  And, they take the heat ratings seriously here. I asked for mine to be 8/10. I'm usually good with the heat but this was a bit too much! (They warned me, so I can't hold it against them.)

hnyvHdDcAa2cqOfrDCPr2Q.text: I was very disappointed with the food here.  I came here with a friend. We shared both the Pad Siew with tofu and the Cashew Chicken.  The flavor was just not there.  The tofu in the Pad Siew was too hardened and overpowered the dish. The Pad Siew lacked enough noodles.  The Cashew Chicken lacked flavor.  We had to add generous amounts of chili sauce to both dishes to try and consume both the dishes.  We didn't finish our plates. I was really disappointed considering what we paid.  There aren't many thai options on the strip.  But if you are craving thai I would go off the strip or wait till you return home.  I would never come here again.   There are plenty of other eat around the strip that are well worth the visit.

igBawM-V87ntJg3lvgS7tg.text: Don't be drawn away from this restaurant simply because of the 3 stars, please. The food is very good! I had the lemongrass chicken, the mint basil chicken, the spicy egplant chicken, and the chicken w/ peanut sauce (yes, shared). While the food was good, it was overpriced for Thai cuisine. Considering the hotel it's in, and the town, the price is rediculously cheap. Now, considering it is thai food, the ambiance and presentation were much better than most quality thai restaurants.  If you want a repleneshing meal that is actually good for you while in vegas, scope this place out!

qL8PxDGJsQsbAgalb6XJ8g.text: So many delicious vegetarian options to pick from! Great ambiance and good service. One of my most favorite restaurants in Vegas. You must try the fresh coconut water, its served in the whole fresh coconut and i felt like i was transported to a tropical island. Definitely worth going back here next time I'm in town!

h7qi_rLB4gcEC3r-BjNWZw.text: This place is pretty good, but not amazing. I went with a bunch of friends and we all tried a bit of what each other had. The pho was just okay. I've had much better! The Sesame Chicken was pretty good, but tasted more like Sweet & Sour sprinkled with sesame seeds and was a little heavy on the sauce. Not bad - but just not what I would call "Sesame chicken". One friend had a vegetarian dish and it was good. The rice doesn't come with the meals so we ordered chicken fried rice to share with the table and it was pretty decent. The chicken, itself, wasn't great but the rice and egg were good. The cashew chicken was the real winner of the table. Generous portion and lots of amazing veggies! It could easily be shared! I wouldn't make a priority of coming to this place again or anything, but if you're staying at The Aria its good food, open late, and reasonably priced compared to other Vegas restaurants.

x20Xd8WA3IPeKku_dmQJRg.text: The best Thai food I have had so far in the US. And these guys know what Thai spicy is all about! Awesome food and by comparison, fairly good value for money. The place is open till late so good for a wholesome meal after a binge at the tables/slots or the site seeing walks!

RPJZtt-w4V8Cx8FdACOD5g.text: Lets see. SERVICE was not so bad, but it sure was freakin slow....FOOD was exceptional, I favored the pineapple fried rice and thats about it...I hate that you have to pay  $3 for a bowl of steamed rice, The atmosphere felt good though, the decor helped make it ambient, attractive, and at the same time quiet relaxing, late night open restaurant...thats a thumbs up! Yes, its Vegas, but still some restaurants or eats are hard to find. The pho was well, but other than fried rice and pho, the food was just eh....the prices you know..its Vegas...as the flight attendant said...lost wages.

xRNPvcMxVLPEFak8ou0NOA.text: I had lunch here during a recent Vegas vacation and the overall experience was excellent. The staff was helpful and attentive. The potstickers were good, but nothing extraordinary. I had the special, which was sea bass, and my date had the pho. The sea bass was delicious and prepared perfectly. My date said it was her new favorite pho. We then shared the mango coconut sticky rice, at the suggestion of our server, and were pleasantly surprised by this subtle dessert. Overall the staff, atmosphere and food made for a superb dining experience.

HZWKVMcmJS2Unn924UXG1Q.text: Ok for me is the best food in Vegas , I love the food there , it like going to thailand in Vegas , my best meal is the chicken curry soap .. You should ask them number 4 , that hot but not to much for me , the only problem is that it take time to get your meal , the place is very busy and you need to have a reservation ready before you  Other meal you should try is the tofu , the steak is really good , but ask the sauce to be on top of it ..   the chicken wings is Not good , so I think 4 star is good for this place ... Enjoy !!!

t5vuSzVXgUDK3EiGZK6zeA.text: New dim sum discovery! I am not a dim sum diva, but I was excited to discover they do have the option. We went on a Sunday afternoon, and were surprised to see a list of dumplings on the table. The cart doesn't come around too often, which could be frustrating. From the cart we selected the soup and the spinach and shrimp dumplings. They weren't as piping hot as I might have enjoyed, and the soup dumplings weren't as soupy as your dreams. However, the taste, especially of the shrimp/spinach, was excellent. I would get those again. Plus, the environment is about 5 times nicer than your usual dim sum establishment. We also sampled the chicken wings this time around, and they were surprisingly delicious. Their soft tofu is superb in their curries. They don't take it easy on the spice though, so be careful what you ask for. We also tried the Three Cups Chicken, but for the price and execution, you're better off doubling down on the chicken wings!

lNP_TvT7hSfS0qTm6cgvYQ.text: I love love love Thai food! This is not my absolute favorite because it is not authentic Thai food as you would have at a hole in the wall but it is very good. It has a different taste to, not as bold as the authentic Thai, however, still very good. I ended up falling asleep on the table here as I was very drunk lol.

l8ED4br4tf7PBYRafxHglw.text: Great place if you really need Asian food love they chicken satay and curry chicken located in aria vip I do recommend this resturant to everyone

pN4hqX_6Bb8nxu_9U720cw.text: Are you people on crack? This food was downright awful! First time in Vegas, and I was ready for some awesome food. We were staying at the Aria, and Thai is one of my favorite cuisines, so I thought we'd play it safe by eating at Lemongrass.  We started with calamari, one of my favorite foods, and it was chewy, bland, and all around blah. The other appetizer we got was the jellyfish, which is probably the only thing I would recommend--loved the sesame flavor. My entree, the Drunken Noodles, was horrendous. Flavor was bland even though I requested it "very spicy" and the seafood was even worse. It seemed like they just cooked it separately and threw it on top, and it wasn't even that fresh. Maybe the Southwest just isn't an Asian food mecca, but I didn't think Central Pennsylvania was either, and I have had much better Thai food back home. This food isn't just Americanized, it's gross, and especially at this price I'd definitely recommend getting your Thai fix elsewhere. To top it off, the service was a little too pushy for my taste...they kept trying to get us to order more! It was creepy!  On that note, I highly recommend the drinks here, and the atmosphere is nice. Next time I'll stick to the bar and jellyfish (well, I don't think there will be a next time actually. Sorry, Lemongrass).

GCNQGAM5KEo56ZZwJmacsA.text: This restaurant is perfect for a top notch casual dinner. The atmosphere is great, the dishes are authentic Thai, most drinks we got were made on the stronger side. A meal for four people with two rounds of drinks was less than 100$. My new favorite Thai restaurant on the Strip!

5I7ditnXQxPjjUULpYXOaA.text: Great traditional Thai! I highly recommend Lemongrass

59-U2Oa7VcYID35jHYLXnQ.text: Looked for some YUM... Got Meh. Service = meh. Oh well.... Lobster Tom Kha - salty! But there were nice big chucks of lobster. 3.5/5 Green curry with Chicken - pass. 2/5 Crab omelette - our server raved about it. We barely touched it. Meh. 2/5

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Lobster Tom Kha. Big chucks of lobster but salty.
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Green curry with Chicken. Pass....
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab omelette - expected more along the Korean --- or Taiwanese oyster pancake. Nope. It was just as stated. Crab. Egg. Basil.

jTLn9lQteTdLVJ0uv1tv9w.text: Food was great service was OK we had a large birthday  Party.   Beautiful  decor oh did I say the Thai food is great

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Right outside the restaurant .oh yes the food was very good!!
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our birthday girl Gina

Vas9-_NorG8ye_ebnHYJ4A.text: I tried Lemongrass twice during my stay at Aria this past weekend. The first time was great! I ordered the chicken pad thai with a spice level of 1. It was promptly served, a good sized portion, and tastefully flavored. Although it was a bit pricey for pad thai ($18), I understand, given the location.  My second experience was through the delivery service. Our group ordered multiple dishes to be delivered to our SkySuite. I decided upon the Duck Noodle Soup. Given I've had duck noodle soup multiple times before, and had a great experience at the restaurant the night prior, I was extremely excited for my meal! However, after taking the first bite, I realized that might not be the case. The soup was extremely salty. The noodles were very thin and undercooked. There was a good amount of duck, but considering the soup base and noodles were not good, the one good part was not enough to salvage the meal. My friends who got Pho said their meal was amazing, which is odd, considering Pho is not even thai food. I only consumed about 1/3 of my meal, before giving up. Another friend ordered the duck noodle soup and had the same thoughts as me. Definitely a disappointing experience.

qm_Y3JbmibJUoDitFJw6Gw.text: Sat at the bar on a busy night. I had the chicken wings which were absolutely delicious. The pork neck is incredible. I could eat that on my own for days. Service was excellent as well.

CKOHwJDeJZBlb-WNmEOXeA.text: Tucked away somewhere complicated to get to in the Aria hotel is lemongrass, a Thai inspired restaurant. The wait was an hour for a busy Sunday night. The food portion sizes are big so I recommend doing a family style and ordering food to share! The food was okay, just basic overpriced pad Thai. The only thing extraordinary about this place was the peanut sauce that comes with the skewers. It was delicious I loved it and so did everyone I was with! The service is okay, not too attentive and a little aloof but they were busy so it was understandable. The chairs and tables are very awkward the table is low and the booth chairs have low backs so it's an awkward sitting situation. The spicy levels are no joke here so if you aren't a fan of spicy I recommend asking for a 1 or 2 because the 3 was very spicy!

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Closest to you (drunken noodles, yellow curry, pineapple rice, pad Thai)

Epr4Pgx0WaDgMFbGk6ZBrQ.text: Trust the other people when they say customer service is bad. It was worse than bad. We were staying in the hotel and thought we would try Lemongrass. Restaurant is pretty. Seated and took a bit to get the waiter to take our order--we should have left then. Ordered and it was a good 20 min before we got the satay we ordered. Then we waited, and waited, and waited 45 more minutes with no food. Waiter never came to say anything. In the meantime, people were seated all around us, ordered and started getting food. A very large party sat next to us and got their food shortly after we finally got ours. Ordered two dishes, finally got one, and had to ask why it was taking so long. Waiter said they "made it wrong and had to remake it." It was a single dish. 4 tables sat around us and ordered and got food within 10-15 min tops. I don't think it takes an hour to remake a dish. We then tried to get the check figuring it would take awhile--we were right. I watched the waiter walk around, stand near the cash register but not print the bill, then get food and serve the table next to me--a party of 6-before even giving us the check. We had to ask AGAIN for the check--he walked away after serving them and still did not get the check. When we asked why it took so ridiculously long to get food, he had some excuse there was a large order in the kitchen. We asked to see the manager, who we learned was Connie, but after sitting awhile we gave up and left. I would never go back here and wish I grabbed some pizza downstairs. I got better service at the bar.

Qc37o5_WXQTpcydb73OzvA.text: The prices here are a bit expensive for what the food is. The beef and pork noodle soup was good. The broth tasted like the authentic my dad makes.   The three stars is due to the fact that most of the meat was chunks of fat and my choy had dirt in it. I didn't realize until the last piece because I but down and felt the grit in my teeth. There was also dirt at the bottom of my bowl from not washing the vegetable thoroughly. For such an expensive bowl of noodles I would've expected cleanliness...

zKSo4_P7-m85OxFPTz4nVA.text: My First Time !! ( Vegetarian )  Greeting : We had to wait for 2 hours.   Attitude of the people around there serving : Ok.  Beverages : Green Tea was good.   Main Course :   Fried Rice : It was served well, delicious and well portioned.  Yellow Curry : Very delicious.   Overall : The food was good.  Service : Decent.  Ambience : Very elegant.  Overall : The experience was good.   Will I go next time : Not sure.

cdVhmqXsSgwgEuogzKnX_w.text: A great location and amazing decorations. Lemongrass is prime real estate next to the high limit casinos inside Aria Resort and Casino. A LOT of employees, so great customer service. Food was great, and was the perfect dish size. Food was definitely a good value for what you get. Ordered Pad See Ew, Me Gooreng, Coconut Curry, Thai Iced Coffee, and the Iceberg Dessert. Come out and try this place if you are ever in the area!

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UUxnTLk5GPydJ0EGuHWMgQ.text: I literally just finished dinner there.... truly disappointed. I saw the ratings but decided to give it a chance. I should have known better when I was "greeted" but the hosts. Both of them were unfriendly, rude and never smiled once. Our waiter was also the same! In regards to food, you can get better at a food truck. All of the dishes had zero /taste/flavors! I've been to two restaurants in Aria so far and both were extremely disappointing.

tcAe7xZxuifzkqzTATbbGQ.text: I don't know what's wrong with this place ! After sitting down , no service at all !!!!! Worst service I ever had in Las Vegas !!!!!!!

K1NCdTeY9Vds3AEAcrB0hA.text: Love this place and will definitely return on our next trip to Las Vegas.  We ate here for lunch and they were still serving dim sum.  Although the dim sum isn't totally authentic, the items we had were still really good! We enjoyed several of the items off of the regular menu as well.  I can't remember the names of the dishes but one was a mixed seafood salad that had a nice kick to it and the other was wonton noodle soup.  I wouldn't recommend the wonton noodle soup because it was bland but it was the only disappointment in the whole meal.

LQIphxLIQNRNxFEHMlZgwQ.text: We ended up at Lemongrass for a late dinner since it's one of the only restaurants open past 10:30p in Aria.  Situated towards the back of the hotel on the casino level, Lemongrass sits next to the Baccarat room & Blossom restaurant. Lemongrass has a relaxing vibe, both beautiful and modern inside - lots of dark woods, sleek booths, and eye-catching, large lantern lightings.  We ordered the Tom Yam Talay soup to start. Lemongrass ranks spiciness as mild, medium, hot, and very hot. We chose our soup to be medium/hot and it came out very spicy!! We love the heat but wow that soup was difficult to enjoy. Either way, the spicy, creamy broth was filled with all types of delicious seafood & had a great mix of lemongrass and ginger flavors. The abalone mushrooms were so tender and yummy too!  We were not too hungry so we decided to share the Singapore Noodles.  Wow, these servings are large! Surprisingly we weren't asked our desired spice level for this dish, and actually found it a bit bland. While we weren't particularly impressed with the noodles--it wasn't better or worse than your typical Thai hole-in-the-wall spot--the portion size is perfect for big eaters who want to dine at a fancier restaurant without breaking the bank.  Overall Lemongrass ranks at 3.5 stars. We weren't really blown away by the food but the ambiance is very beautiful and cozy.

2NDk_iTd4p5Uhk4mlE8nEg.text: OK listen, I get it...you are in a swank hotel, you have a trendy ambiance but your food is just "OK" at best and your service a bit pretentious...get over yourself!  This is the second time I have dined at Lemongrass (previously lunch) and now dinner...both times, same exact experience.  The staff has serious attitude over God knows what.  Vegas is a tourist destination at the end of the day and service should be front and center every time, for every customer. Lemongrass is kidding itself if they think otherwise.  The food is just average...Thai food is usually good at most places...this is your typical fancy Thai spot that just misses the mark.  The spring rolls are average, the cucumber salad...meh.  The penang curry w/shrimp had a slight kick so was the best thing we ate since it actually had decent flavor. The pad thai was just plain boring.  Wine selection is average...nothing crazy but then again, at a Thai restaurant, can't come in expecting spectacular vino selection.  Please do yourself a favor and skip the nonsense...find a hole in the wall Thai resto off the strip and satisfy your belly and your experience.  Again, the snooty service is the biggest turn off here.

5Ne6EdOHqdXLS5gbby5m8w.text: Not impressed.  Decent Thai food, but nothing out of the ordinary to justify the $18/dish price point.  Ambiance and decor were nice, as expected for being located in the beautiful Aria hotel, however the restaurant itself was quite loud which made conversation difficult.  Spice level was on point, the lack of which is such an annoyance to me at most Thai restaurants.  I think they really followed the Thai Hot scale on this one.  The spice level masked the lack of flavor in most of the dishes.  We took home leftovers but never ate them.  I think that says something in itself...

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Green curry
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pad Thai

93gzVH5rTjXJ9Nf0YtNP2g.text: I hate giving this low rating because I really loved the restaurant, but I had the weirdest experience here with my food, and it definitely needs to be addressed.   I ordered the Dungeness Crab Curry dish, one of the most expensive dishes on the menu which I had no problem with...until it was served. The chef very much needs to re-think the way this dish is done because it kind of blows my mind that it was presented the way it was, clearly created for presentation instead of practicality. The waitress, who seemed to be timid and not friendly, served it with nothing that I needed to eat it with. I'll admit it might have been a slight miscomprehension on my part because the description did say whole- but never did I imagine they would serve it with the shell totally intact. This restaurant is a very nice upscale place, so this dish has no business being served inside of the shell- I was going to wear a very nice dry-clean only dress and had changed at the last minute, if I hadn't we would have had a very big problem. I digress...there were no utensils except chopsticks and they had gone as far as to remove the top shell of the crab, gut it, and place it back on top so it has an awesome presentation- but I needed to treat it like an actual crab picking fest including cracking the shell and digging for the meat. Okay, I can deal with that- except they had cooked it with the curry so going through the arduous process of digging the meat out was made MUCH harder because it was now coated in slimy curry. I do not understand how they thought this was practical, by the time I had dug out enough meat everything was cold! Before I commenced with the operation of slaving for my bit of crab meat, I had no idea what to do with it. I thought maybe I could eat it with my chopsticks and sat there poking around for a good 15 minutes when finally the waitress came to check on us and I asked her how I was supposed to eat it. She said "I'll get you some crackers and a bowl and teach you how to eat it" I really wish she had explained all of this to me before ordering because I would never have spent the money on this otherwise. So she comes back with two extra bowls (one for the shells and one for the final assembly) and tells me that once I'm done cracking it open, I put the meat in the bowl with some of the steamed rice and scoop the rest of the curry dish into it and eat it that way. I mean WTF! Firstly, why present it that way at all? Why not cook the crab separately then remove the meat, put it in with the curry dish, and do your cute little presentation with the top crab shell so that people don't have to get incredibly messy and take forever to eat a simple dish at an extremely nice upscale restaurant?! Please explain how any of that makes sense.  Aside from all that ridiculousness, the shrimp appetizer dish we had was very good. My husband ordered fried squid and I didn't like it all but the duck sauce it came with was much better with the shrimp thingy. My husband didn't seem overly wowed by his dish choice of drunken noodles but didn't dislike it either. There were a lot of other dishes I was interested in and I wish I had just sucked up my pride and asked for my dish to be taken back once seeing how stupidly involved it was. This was our last dinner of the trip and I gave up trying other places I wanted to go to because the menu here sounded good, but this stupid dish ruined it the night. I hated that I was so absolutely messy and the curry stained my nails and fingers, nothing I did took away the greenish yellow tinge and smell until I got home and had my nails redone.

A1O7JDWiYxEJHdnvK1LK3Q.text: One cannot really expect authentic Thai food from a restaurant in a fancy schmany Vegas hotel.   Knowing that, the food is good. My uncle reserved the private room for my family to celebrate my mom's birthday, and he preordered the food ahead of time so I don't know what everything was called.   He also ordered way too much food, not knowing what the portions would be like, which are decent-sized. We had pad thai, some sort go orange chicken, tilapia, fried rice, etc, but the two that stood out to me were the crab cake/pancake (my little brother is annoyingly picky, but he loved this dish) and the seafood curry (nice spices, and it was different from everything else I've tasted).   I also ordered one of their specialty drinks, the Berry Botanical, which was a green tea infused gin with whole blueberries. It was really refreshing, and they were not stingy with the alcohol, which I appreciate.   The ambience is what you would expect of Vegas, trendy, clean and modern with dim, mood lighting. The service was great. My family didn't like the tiny individual plates they gave us, and our server was more than happy to replace them with bigger plates.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Berry Botanical specialty cocktail: green tea infused gin!
Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Feast in the private room for a birthday dinner!

eCpsFCP_qBZ_b9d-cEmT0g.text: Was in Vegas for work. Came by Lemongrass because coworkers recommended it.   Ordered Thai Basil Soup with Meatballs, Pork Satay and Singaporean Noodles. While the food was decent, the service was awful. They were quick to bring out food and that was it. No one came to ask if everything was good and if I needed anything else. That's the bare minimum a restaurant/waiter can do. Had to ask someone to get my leftovers to go. Had to ask for the check twice. The total came out to be $41+ and paid $50 in cash. Never came back for the change. Had to ask them for it. There's no way I was going to leave $8+ tip for such a dismal service.   In a city where they get tons of tourists who probably don't tip and will never see again, I suppose it's ok to have subpar service. If that's your cup of tea, feel free to patron Lemongrass.

photos.caption: Photo of Lemongrass - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Thai Basil Soup with Meatballs and Pork Satay.

v4uLVB1ZxMMn2AgpZFJfHQ.text: Every time we go to Vegas, whether we stay at Aria or not, we ALWAYS go to Lemongrass.  The food is usually very good and it's great that they're open late - 2:00 am.  I must say, however, that our visit this past weekend, 12:10 am early Sunday morning, was a bit off.  My wife ordered the Drunken Noodle, a dish she orders at practically every Thai restaurant we go to, and the noodles were, let's say "different".  They were chopped up rather than the usual long strands and they looked like they had been sitting a while.  BUT more importantly, the dish was room temperature!  Not something you'd expect with seafood.  I asked our waiter to send it back; however, when he returned with a plate, the dish did not appear to be fresh and it was initially hot but cooled off quickly.  So, clearly it was not a fresh order and it appeared as if it was placed in a microwave since it didn't retain its heat.  Well, needless to say, this wasn't the best experience we've had at Lemongrass, as it's usually VERY good.  Not sure what happened this time around but for those interested, I'd certainly give this restaurant a try.

Uy_KYbgmCRZe3ASD4ahgdA.text: Love, love!  I ordered takeout from Lemongrass, and the food was ready even before the estimated wait time.  The customer service was excellent and the employees were very friendly.  I ordered the pad thai and it was outstanding!  There was a balance of spice and sweet, with a great crunch from the peanuts on top.  It was even served with Sriracha and a lime to squeeze on top.  Loved the food!  One of my favorites so far in Las Vegas.

LYBYaXs2aYQV-tT8_17diQ.text: Best Thai restaurant I've ever been to. The decor and space is beautiful. Service was not that great as we had to wait a long time for our waiter to bring us our check. The food was very good. The drunken noodles were some of the best I've ever had, and I've eaten a lot of drunken noodles. Apart from the questionable service this place was great. Food is fiercely spicy, so definitely go mild on the 1-10 spicy scale if you're not used to spicy food.

ZUGohmRl3zNJsi0j4RIVQA.text: We ended up here after my boyfriend's father was craving Asian & we wanted something on the cheaper end of Vegas dining. We also love Thai food and are frequent patrons of Thai restaurants. This place still is Strip-priced, (expect $16+ for fried rice or chow mein), but was decent for where we were.  The atmosphere is nice with dark booths and dim lighting. The service was friendly, but were not as attentive as I would have liked.   I ordered the vegetarian pad see-ew, which comes with flat rice noodles, broccoli, egg, & tofu. Simple. It also had a green leaf next to it on the menu indicating one of the vegetarian options- which I loved and appreciated. Regardless, when I got my meal (& I was so ravenous I just dug in), my 1st bite was a mix of white tofu & white CHICKEN!!! UGH!!! Manners & impressing the boyfriend's parents pushed aside, I immediately spit up the contents in my napkin. I have been a vegetarian for 17 years now, that was absolutely disgusting & such an inappropriate mistake for a restaurant to make. Also, why on earth would the kitchen staff put in two proteins?! They clearly charge you double for adding extra protein, & this was one of the specially marked vegetarian entrees. Normally I inspect my meals just in case, but I was just so hungry & trusting... It took a long time to get someone's attention to make it right, & they had to remake my dish while I sat there hungry watching everyone else eat. We were also in a hurry that night as we had after dinner plans. When I finally got my new dish, it had no meat, but it was much drier than the original dish. It also did not taste Thai, or like pad see ew, it was like regular Chinese chow fun. Very disappointing.   The other people in our party ordered the basil beef fried rice, shrimp curry, beef chow fun, & chicken curry, & each enjoyed their meals. I would still recommend this place if you are craving Asian cuisine in Vegas, but beware, vegetarians!

N-8h3BAr2YuiwVZcE3QgJw.text: We wanted pho and asian food.. we didnt want to drive far to get some asian food and they have good reviews so we came here.  My friends ordered pho and dimsum my bf and i ordered pad see wu and sweet amd sour chicken.. surprisingly pad see wu was good not the sweet and sour chicken. The pho was very diffrent from how we normally eat it. The pho had a strong taste cinnamon.. not use to that.  Dimsum was really good too. It had a very clean taste not salty or oily. Last-i love thai tea. Thai tea was very good :)

i8atKeU6BqB-9vbb8Xq2lw.text: I loved everything about this restaurant. It serves a full menu after 11 pm. The service was great; my water glass was never more than half empty before it was refilled. I ordered prawn satay which had a delicious peanut sauce and duck panag curry. We ordered our food medium spicy and it was spicy but not overly so. The duck was perfectly tender mixed well with all the flavors in the dish. The portions were very large so I recommend sharing an entree if you aren't too hungry.

_KzyJ58DiHuWeKV5iTgeEw.text: Lemongrass is located inside Aria hotel right next to blossom. I came here for lunch two days ago with a party of about 10. The service was awful. When we sat down, there was no waiter to be found anywhere near by. I kept having to turn my head back and forth just so I can wave one down. I had to walk to the hostess stand to ask for some menu's to look at. By the time the waiter came, we were ready to order.   I ordered the thai tea as my beverage. It took almost 10 minutes to come out. The thai tea wasn't sweet enough. I've had better.   My boyfriend & I shared the jellyfish and the Lemongrass prawns as the appetizers. I don't recommend the jellyfish. It was too largely cut that it was so hard to chew. I wish it was thinly sliced. So the "Lemongrass prawns" came out. And it looks like a fishcake or something. So I asked the waiter what it was and he said fish cake. I told him we didn't order that and that was ordered prawns. So he added that in as well. Then the "prawns" came out and it was an eggroll prawn. There was 3 different waiters at this table and they were all saying different things. Finally we verified that it was the Lemongrass prawn and just turn into a mousse. The Lemongrass Prawns was actually pretty decent. It was just a hassle to figure out what everything was.   As our entree we ordered the drunken noodles with seafood. It was okay. The portion was kind of small. There wasn't enough flat noodles. It was about $20 for this dish.   I thought this restaurant was pretty pricey for an "Asian" restaurant. And it wasn't even satisfying.

RY2T48wNBoGsucF0vBMJFg.text: We stayed at the ARIA and decided to get take out from here one night. The Tom Kha Gai was sooo good & the mixed veggies & rice we're great too. Fresh ingredients and quick service

FheC2Ue5yzPw6YX7O02Pkw.text: Ambiance is nice and staff are very polite. However the food wasn't great. I had shrimp basil with undercooked cold shrimp. The noodles were very dry. The Sticky Rice was almost like me cutting through a brick lol. Maybe it was just a bad night for me

IF60-k20OKstCywl9r0-YA.text: I loved it! Service was excellent, food even better! I got noodles that were out of this world with flavor, never had better to this day. Also tried my friends meal which was some kind of spicy beef that also rocked! And good god, for dessert I tried the coconut soup, yes for dessert you heard me right haha. I can't say it was like a broth because it was way creamy, it is served warm and is supposed to cleanse your palate before you eat a "real dessert" as my fiance would say (which I'm not gonna lie,I ate most of his fried bananas too). Just typing this makes me want that soup sooooo bad! I can't describe how yummy it is. Also side note- fried bananas were terrific as well, they use plantain and are the best I have tried so far, great sauce on it and a ton of ice cream is put on the side of it.  You can even order a coconut with the milk in it to drink out of! Will be back...  And soon, cuz now I want that soup!

is2L9TErzVlUCu87tBMGTQ.text: I was actually really happy with the food and service!! Its thai food with a bit of a twist... honestly, it all tasted great but a little sweet. besides the wings being a bit dry:  The panang was awesome. Shrimps (any dish) were great, nice size.  Satay was good along with their Peanut sauce!! Noodles were good Service was good as well...  Thai iced tea, not to sweet, was good!  All together the good and everything was good, no complaints, would go here again.

pMD1ZVK1fJa9cWMemtVWjA.text: Food was good . Nice flavors good temp. The only reason I'm giving it any stars was because of the food. AS FOR THE SERVICE.... one of the worst I've ever experienced. No refils, no asking us if our food was fine, waited 45 mins for our check and couldn't find our server.  We finally noticed him messing and chatting away with the cooks and some other servers.. Meh.

MU5y2-v6GG-LbLo9QtpnnA.text: Excellent for large groups, we were a group of 22. Everything we ordered was superb and we sampled a lot of the menu given the size of our group. The best was the soft shell crab salad. Reasonable prices for the Strip. They forgot my wife's wine order for a while but the place was packed that night and the excellent food made up for any service shortcomings.

z7HXVcZ9nIjGf-rEmT8mow.text: Service was lackluster, food was OK tasting, slightly overpriced, and hmmm, let me see... Oh yeah! my wife and I had to take immediate emergency trips to the bathroom after our dinner. Overall extremely disappointing.

PefDWZ96Yf4jh-SfhL3vtg.text: Food was good. Ahead of time reservation would help but luckily we didn't have to wait long for our seats without reservation either.

CzexEqFQNoSJX1t-o0q4wQ.text: Went here on a whim after leaving wet republic. Totally glad they let us in they way we were dressed and slightly intoxicated. We had a party of 9 and was seated within 10 minutes. The design and decor was nice ( what did you expect, it is inside of Aria )   I started with some hot and sour soup which was great. Everyone ordered the satay grill and some chicken wings were ok. I had the basil meat with chicken and asked for level 10 Thai hot. Let me tell you this, it wasn't even a level 5 on a USA hot scale. The dish had flavor but I've had better. Service was very good. All around decent spot to eat, but for 40$ for a basic Thai meal, I can do WAY better. Probably wouldn't come back unless I am staying at Aria.

c9uckS5qQw4vIxeuPCIdPg.text: Waited for ever for the host to appear. Never did. I had to walk into the restaurant and find myself a table. They need an complete overhaul of their staff.   Food was standard thai. It was ok, nothing great though.

AtaEK8RLrh8HMa_NFAW9kw.text: We made a reservation online and when we got to Lemongrass we were told that as we made the reservation 2 minutes ago, they will not honor it. Their reason was that the got some walk-ins that they did not registered on their computer system so their reservation program allowed us to book the reservation.  WT!!!  Who's fault is it that they hired lazy hostesses who doesn't notate the walk ins in their system.  I doubt that we'll come here in the near future.  Wanted to give zero star for service but yelp doesn't allow it.  Don't know how's the food as our reservation was refused.

u7Vu-AVhofFuIcX5293_lA.text: This place was okay. I came in to Lemongrass because I had a 7:00 show to Zarkana and we needed a quick fix before we went in.   I really like the decor of the small but intimate restaurant. Very cute design. However, if you end up being seated at the booth, those booth chairs are SUPER uncomfortable to sit at. The booths are shorter so it kind of forces you to sit up straight the entire time. I couldn't relax and rest my back onto it without sitting up straight. I guess that's good for my posture but man, imagine sitting up straight for an entire dinner! Sure would have made my mom happy!!  We ordered a various kinds of food. Green curry, pad see ew, shrimp soup, and cashew chicken. All was good but nothing spectacular. For the prices you're paying, I'd say it's nothing that great you couldn't get at a smaller and cheaper Thai joint.   Like I said, it was okay. I enjoyed my green curry but don't enjoy the price I'm paying for it. Would I come back? Depends. If I'm short on time like last time I'll probably stop by here again, but it's probably not on my go to spots here in Vegas.

k8-ZBtuO0vBt7eojAPLgVg.text: I thought the food was great, and the price was high and the service was lacking. I would recommend but know the service is not the best or close to it.

8y1ZqvNEGx6VzyON4Lkpkg.text: A group of us dined here for a business gathering and the food and service were wonderful. I ordered the red seafood curry and it was spectacular!  So much so that I've tried several times to re-create it once I returned home :)). The appetizers were fabulous also!  We will be returning next year!

53hhQdPFH5o8SjP8ELLsMw.text: Lemongrass does a pretty decent job at selecting authentic Thai dishes. However, dishes that were tasted did not stand out from other Thai restaurants (e.g. pad thai, sweet and sour chicken). Though some of the dishes may not have that "wow factor," there are some that are pretty decadent. I'm talking about their red curry. It's amazingly flavorful immaculate Thai dish. Just make sure to not order it too spicy otherwise you won't get to indulge in its rich flavor. Try out the coconut ice cream. It is sublime.
